âMy question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Would the Prime Minister inform the House of any additional steps the government proposes to take to ensure full compliance with the national agreement on firearms control reached in 1996?

âI thank the honourable member for Wakefield for that question. As I know all members of the parliament are aware and the Australian public is aware, the agreement willingly and freely entered into by all states and territories and the Commonwealth in 1996 brought to this country an unprecedented prohibition on the possession and use of dangerous firearms and was in response to an outraged Australian community in the wake of the Port Arthur tragedy. That particular decision represented a collective determination by the governments of Australia, representing the people of Australia, to reject in this country the gun culture and to avoid Australia going down the path of the United States.

answer.para: I think it is fair to say that, overwhelmingly, that agreement has worked well; that there have been hundreds of thousands of weapons reclaimed in the buyback, which was financed by a special Medicare levy; that those weapons have been destroyed; and that Australia is undeniably a safer country, particularly for women and children, than it was before the nationwide agreement was concluded in 1996. It is therefore a matter of some concern to my government, and I think it would be a matter of concern to all members of this House, that there are some signs that some jurisdictions are endeavouringâhowever much at the periphery that endeavour may beâto water down in some way the national agreement.

I want to say on behalf of the government that we are totally opposed to any watering down of the national agreement. It had been my intention at the Premiers Conference last Friday to put a proposition to the premiers and chief ministers to the effect that, firstly, all present should endorse the national agreement concluded in 1996, that there should be an examination and a report to the next COAG meeting about the extent of compliance with that agreement by the various jurisdictions and that in the meantime no state or territory government should take any action at all that could be regarded as watering down the agreement.

It is now a matter of record that the premiers and chief ministers chose to leave that meeting and deliberately rejected my suggestion that the matter should be discussed. As a consequence of that, I have examined what steps can be taken by the Commonwealth to further strengthen observance of that agreement, having in mind the fact that the Commonwealth has no direct constitutional power to prohibit the sale of firearms in the various states. As a result of that, any action that we might be able to take under existing constitutional power would be limited to our authority regarding customs and some other matters, perhaps including the taxation power.

I am therefore pleased to inform the House that as a first step the government will be putting a recommendation to His Excellency the Governor-General this afternoon so that, with effect from midnight tonight, there will be a ban introduced on the importation of weapons designated as category C in the 1996 agreement. The two exceptions allowed under that agreement are primary producers, subject to a police authorisation test which requires the police to certify that the user is a primary producer; and, secondly, sporting shooters, subject to a test that they meet the narrow exception for clay target shooters in the agreement. That will require the written authority of the Commonwealth Attorney-General.

The amendments to the customs regulation will also allow licensed dealers to import a limited number of such firearms to be kept in bond for use by individuals who meet the tests and to take effect once appropriate custodial arrangements are in place. That is the first step being taken by the government to further strengthen compliance with the agreement.

Let me say again to the states, let me say again to the premiers of all states, that the overwhelming desire of the Australian people, wherever they live, is to have full compliance with this agreement. We have limited constitutional power in this matter; the states have most of the constitutional power. I say again: we will use all of the constitutional power we have to enforce observance of the agreement. I hope a like attitude is taken by all premiers and all chief ministers.

Prime Minister, every single major point of your guidelines to ensure the honesty and the appearance of honesty of your ministersânot just the honesty of them; the appearance of honesty of your ministersâyou have permitted Parer to breach. What did you say about your guidelines? You said that they were only meant to apply to non-dependent kids. So a judgment was arrived at by the Prime Minister, clearly, on the implication of that, that Short was not. That is the implication of what the Prime Minister had to say, though I do not recollect him saying it at the time. But what did the Prime Minister so bravely say when he wanted to score a point off us as he dramatically presented his guidelines on 7 May 1996? He said this to the parliament as he wrapped himself in his cloth of unction, as he so often does in this place:

That was the Prime Minister on 7 May 1996. These are the incredible shrinking guidelines. But, after the resignations of Jim Short and Brian Gibson, the tone in October 1996 was a little less strident:

Then, as John Moore entangled himself in the guidelines, the Prime Minister said on 14 October 1996:

Again, on 15 October:

Yes, Prime Minister, they are. Those indeed are the guidelinesâand the Hawke and the Keating and the Fraser governments managed to observe them. And, I might say, so did the Menzies government manage to observe those guidelinesâand, when ministers failed to observe those guidelines, out the door those ministers went.

What an extraordinary series of statements the Prime Minister has made to various people who have interviewed him on these things. He came out and said to John Stanley on 2UEâand recollect his defence here on Parer:
Both Gibson and Short were technically in breach, and in those circumstances they had to go. They are the rules.
Then he goes on:
I mean a lot of people are saying to me, `John, you're too tough, this is an unreasonable unreal standard.' Now I don't think it is.

The Prime Minister had specific questions put to him by me here today which I would have thought would have been simple for any other Prime Ministerânot just himself, but any other Prime Ministerâto answer, if those questions had been put to him in this place at the times in which other governments were in office in this country. Does a prohibition continue to apply on a minister owning shareholdings in his portfolios? It is simple; it is a simple, straightforward statement to preserve the integrity of our political system, Prime Ministerâan integrity that you cannot uphold. You are getting a bit used to your ministers, which is one of the reasons why you are in full retreat on the standards of honesty you put in place and the standards of integrity you put in place, you said, to run this countryâand these were the standards of honesty and integrity that had applied for a very lengthy period of time.

I can recollect you on so many occasions saying that these sorts of standards, this sort of outlook on life is what has meant that federal politics in this country have been kept free of corruptionâand, indeed, they have been basically free of corruption. In that regard, it is almost unique in federal systems around the world that the national parliament should experience that. But what has kept us there?

What has kept us there is that we do not have Bjelke-Petersen standards in this place. What has kept us there is that we have these sorts of standards of integrity. That is what has kept us honest. One of those things that has kept us honestâand nobody needs to look further than the sorts of state government operations which have occurred over the last 30 or 40 years in this country; nobody needs to look further than the experience of those particular state governments with what occurs when a minister has a set of business interests or potential ownership interests in a particular operation, and decisions are subsequently taken, to know how important in the preservation of the integrity of our federal systemâis the set of guidelines that you have reissued. Nobody ought know better than you, who have been in politics for a very long time period of time, how very significant those guidelines are.

Every now and then, of course, in extremity, we get some real reasons tickled out. Is the real reason here as to why he is being let offâaccording to Senator Parer's staffâthe fact that Senator Parer is a good bloke? Is the real reason here that, somehow or other, black is white, and we have found a totally new interpretation of the guidelines? Is that why Senator Parer's staff feel that he is going to stay and he is thoroughly protected?

No. What we have here is a spokesperson for Senator Parer who said that Mr Howard was standing by his minister because he was concerned that, if the senator resigned, the opposition would then move to pick off each of the other ministers with family trusts. Nineteen government frontbenchers have family trust arrangements. So the position of the Prime Minister is this: if there is a family trust arrangement that involves you in a clash of interests potentially with your portfolio, then you must ignore it.

You have finally come to this position. It has finally come to this: as far as the Prime Minister is concerned now, he does not believe that his ministers can meet what has been a traditional standard of integrity. As far as the operations of this parliament and these governing processes since time immemorial in this country, he cannot be protected any longer. That standard cannot be protected any longer by this Prime Minister leading this government.

That may be all right for the Prime Minister. But, if you ask us a question as to why we raise these issues day after day in question time, Prime Minister, the reason why we raise these issues day in and day out in question time is this: one of the duties of an opposition is to hold the government accountable. One of the duties of an opposition is to uphold standards which go beyond governments. They are there for governments, whether Labor, Liberal or any other particular coalition of interests in this country. They are out there to ensure that the people of this nation are governed impartially by whoever happens to be the government of the dayâand so that people in this nation can be assured and can take the view, and can take some comfort in the view, that, whatever else is going on, nobody there in politics is enriching themselves, nobody there in politics is in any way sullied in their decision making by a feeling that they have an ownership interest in the issues that relate to their portfolio. That is an absolute requirement of the Australian people.

The Prime Minister tries to get up there and say, `Well, the Labor Party is engaging in the politics of envy.' When did I last hear a leader of a government talk like that; when did I last hear it? The last person I heard who persistently argued that position was none other than Joh Bjelke-Petersenâ`Ministers are not meant to have the seat out of their pants. You're just all envious of Russ Hinze. That's what you're all worried about. You are envious of Russ Hinze. That's why you're raising the complaints. You're envious of me; you're envious of the fact that I run a terrific peanut plantation; you're envious of the fact that I have these terrific business interests with all these people who do business with Queensland.' He would continue,`You're not complaining that people may be being disadvantaged; that there is no impartiality in the Queensland government. You're not complaining about corruption. You're not complaining about the sort of thing that destroys people's confidence in the democratic process. No. What you are is envious of us making a bit of money.'

That is what the Prime Minister has finally descended to in his argument. As he stands here, he has the Richard Nixon argumentâ`All other statements I may have made about this are no longer applicable.' He has the Joh Bjelke-Petersen argumentâ`As far as I'm concerned, you're only raising this issue because you feel a sense of envy.'

There is another attribute to this, and it does not go just to the question of whether or not there is a position which in some way or another is a question of impartiality that people can look to and approve of. It goes to the moral authority of the government. What right have you got as a Prime Minister of this nation to stand up and say to any one of your fellow Australians that you are earning your income in a way that is other than from the sweat of your brow, that you are earning your income in a way that disadvantages the rest of the Australian community, that you are earning your income in a way that is a product of laziness, that you are earning your income in a way that is a product of moral pressure or whatever on your employers?

What right have you got to stand in this place and make an argument like that while you are prepared to defend the potential rorting of a governing process by your own ministers? In this particular instance he may be a good bloke, and he may not be out there actively enriching himself, but what one of those people whom you lecture so thunderously from the dispatch box hereâand that your Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) entertains so thunderously from the dispatch box and that from time to time your Treasurer (Mr Costello) doesâhave got themselves awarded a 1c share that turns into $56,000 that is still held? While it may not be enriching them, there is capital accruing nevertheless while he happens to be the minister in charge and in authority in this portfolio. He may not receive a disbursement but the disbursements he gets comes through his hands and goes into his children's portfolio. But he sure as heck benefits from the capital gains associated with that and anything that is held in the company which he may subsequently rejoin when he leaves this portfolio.

That is why your guidelines, Prime Minister, which, you are right, you did not invent, are very clear on how you divest. You do not divest to such a group of people because you can rejoin them. You divest to people completely unassociated with you. That is what you do. You do not divest to your children, be they adults or be they juniors. You do not divest to your wife. You divest. That is what your rules say, and Senator Parer did. He is not here acting in ignorance. Senator Parer did that with a set of shares for BHP, for Santos and for CSRâhe divested. He did not divest to anyone in his family. He divested. In fact, his family makes a positive point on that; that within the family trust itself they divested of a series of these shares when the minister took office because they thought of a potential clash.

I will tell you who is producing that $300,000. It is being produced by the workers in the coalmines with which he is associated and which are subject to repeated abuse for their work practices by this government. If you are going to be the Prime Minister of this country for any length of time, like another three or four months, at least pass your baton on to your successor on the basis of uncompromised standards as far as these issues are concerned. There is always going to be, in any issue about whether or not a person is in conformity with a set of guidelines, finetuning from time to time. There are going to be fine distinctions drawn. There can be no fine distinctions drawn in this caseânone at all, no fine distinctions.

You can only stand here, Prime Minister, and argue that black is white. That is all you can do. For anybody who is interested in listening out thereâand you desperately do not want them to. You have had your cheer squad here in question time today cheering away at members of the gallery saying, `Aren't they a dreadful opposition? Aren't they terrible? talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, I present the following report: Report 357âJindalee Operational Radar Network Project .

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâIn June 1991 Defence entered into a contract with Telstraâor Telecom as it then wasâto acquire a wide-area surveillance capability based on an over-the-horizon radar technology which had been developed in Australia. From the beginning, the JORN project has been bedevilled with technical and management problems which have so far resulted in an increase in the contracted price of over $600 million and a four-year delay in the schedule. On current estimates, Australia will not have a fully operational over-the-horizon radar networkâ which is a crucial element of our surveillance systemâuntil the year 2002. The committee's inquiry revealed deficiencies in almost every aspect of the JORN project: in the process of selecting the prime contractor, in the supervision of the prime contractorâTelstraâby Defence, in the management of the project by Telstra and in the performance of a key subcontractor, GEC-Marconi.

speech.para: In selecting the prime contractor Defence ignored the report of an internal review team which concluded, early in the process, that the best approach would be to select a contractor experienced in over-the-horizon radar technologies and with a proven track record in managing major defence projects. The review team had favoured a US based prime contractor with an Australian company in partnership. The committee is critical of Defence's actions in establishing a review team for the particular purpose of making recommendations on acquiring an over-the-horizon radar network, only to ignore the fundamental assumptions on which its recommendations were based. It is ironic that the company now responsible for completing the JORN project is an American companyâLockheed Martinâwith an Australian company in partnership.

The committee found that Defence exhibited weaknesses in its supervision of the prime contractor. For example, Defence did not intervene early enough or with sufficient rigour to put in place formalised and systematic risk assessment procedures (as required by the contract). Nor did Defence insist on greater Telstra consultation with DSTOâworld renowned experts in the field of over-the-horizon radar. Defence's unwillingness to give progressive approval to Telstra's system designs, while understandable given the terms of the contract, contributed to Telstra's difficulties in finalising and progressing a design capable of meeting JORN's very demanding performance specifications.

Telstra's lack of experience in Defence contracting and its unfamiliarity with contracts written in terms of required functions and performance became evident in the early stages and were to have damaging consequences for the project. The committee also found a lack of commitment by senior Telstra management to the JORN project. Telstra failed to access relevant expertise in Defence project management or systems engineering, failed to develop an effective relationship with DSTO and encountered significant difficulties in its management of a major subcontractor, GEC-Marconi.

The original subcontract between Telstra and GEC-Marconi set out a cumbersome division of responsibilities which contributed to a breakdown in the commercial relationship between Telstra and GEC-Marconi. Remaining unresolved for over three years, the problem of poorly specified interfaces, and the lack of a coherent plan to manage and control hardware and software interface configurations, significantly influenced Telstra's management of the subcontract and impeded progress on the project. The committee is critical that GEC-Marconi, given its experience elsewhere, did not anticipate the difficulties that were inherent in the original subcontract with Telstra. Moreover, the committee was told in the course of the inquiry that GEC-Marconi's inability to deliver transmitters and receivers and associated drivers to quality, performance and time requirements had an adverse impact on the project's cost and schedule.

As you are aware, Mr Deputy Speaker, Telstra has relinquished its management role to a Lockheed Martin-Transfield joint venture company. The future of the JORN project is, however, far from clear. Although Defence asserts that the radar network's performance requirements are technically achievable and the partners in the joint venture company have expressed confidence that the radar network can and will be completed, the committee believes that there are good reasons for a more cautious assessment to be made. Although much has been done to mitigate the technical risks that are still to be confronted, the fact remains that it is in the last years of the project that the high cost, high risk systems integration phase will take place. As Defence's new submarine project has shown, systems integration and testing can be particularly troublesome and time consuming.

Since 1983 the Joint Committee of Public Accounts has examined a number of Defence projects and programs which have revealed Defence's consistent inability to gain value for money. It is essential that Defence addresses project management shortcomings and establishes sound procedures which will ensure that high cost projects are completed within allocated budgets and time frames. The committee believes that it is critical that Defence obtains the best project managers, if necessary from overseas, for major acquisition projects. The problems encountered in the JORN project demonstrate conclusively that Defence should choose appropriately experienced consortiums or companies to acquire its major defence capabilitiesâwith a particular focus on choosing the best project managers.

A broader issue to emerge during this inquiry was the extent of the Commonwealth's liability for cost overruns incurred by the JORN project. In 1991 Defence had negotiated a ceiling price in its contract with Telstra. However, given Telstra's status as a Commonwealth business entity, any additional costs incurred by Telstra over and above the ceiling price to be paid by Defence are costs to the Commonwealth in terms of reduced dividend payments to the government and its shareholders. This is a matter of immense concern to the committee.

In conclusion, I would like to express the committee's appreciation to those people who contributed to the review by preparing submissions and giving evidence at both public and in-camera hearings. I would also like to thank John Alcock from the Department of Defence and Ray McNally from the Australian National Audit Office for their assistance.

Finally, I acknowledge the contribution of the former Chairman of the JCPA, the Hon. Alex Somlyay. Also, on behalf of the committee, I thank the members of the sectional committee for their time and their dedication in conducting what has been a very complex and an extremely lengthy inquiry. I also thank the secretariat staff who have assisted in the conduct of the inquiry: Gillian Gould, Laura Gillies and, at an earlier stage of the inquiry, Maureen Chan, Yolanda Rao, Donna Christophers and the secretary to our committee, Margot Kerley. I commend the report to the House.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâI rise to support the remarks of the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), the Chairman of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit, on the inquiry into the Jindalee operational radar networkâJORNâproject. This was a serious investigation by the JCPA into the funding of an important project. The revelations, to say the least, were of concern to all members of the sectional committee, which I had the pleasure of serving on. Indeed, I believe that they should be of concern to all members of this House.

speech.para: Some of the evidence received in this inquiry was breathtaking, to say the least. As we have heard from the member for La Trobe, the committee found deficiencies in almost every aspect of the JORN project. This was a disturbing feature in what was a long and complex inquiry.

The JORN inquiry was well warranted when you consider that the project involved over $1.1 billion of taxpayers' funds. As we have heard, the project is to construct a number of radar facilities which will widen the surveillance capability of the Australian Defence Force. As the committee found out, the project was plagued with managerial and technical problems right from its inceptionâover some seven years ago.

This report by the JCPA primarily sought to find out why this situation developed and what is going to happen to the future of the JORN project. The key players, as the chairman has said, were Telstra Australia, which was the prime contractor; GEC-Marconi, which was a subcontractor responsible for the design and supply of major components of the radar; and Telstar Systems, which was responsible for the radar's software.

The committee, to its great distress, found problems with almost every area of the JORN project. Whether it was with the process of selecting the prime contractor, or the Department of Defence monitoring of the prime contractor, or even in the performance of a key subcontractor, problems were found every step of the way. We were told of GEC-Marconi's inability to deliver transmitters and receivers, and associated drivers to quality, performance and time requirements had a critical impact on the project's costs and schedule. It is interesting to note, as the committee was informed, that it appears that GEC-Marconi had similar problems in defence projects in the United Kingdom. Also there were problems with Telstar in their being unable to meet initial contractual requirements.

I would like to make some remarks about the conduct of the inquiry. The JCPA was able to inspect the long range sky-wave over-the-horizon radar facility at Alice Springs as well as the JORN sites at Longreach. Those members who were able to attend informed me that it was a very useful exercise. Substantial numbers of public hearings were held in Canberra in 1996 and early 1997, and then later in 1997.

We were at all times aware of the sensitivities involved with the project and, as such, evidence was often taken in camera. This unfortunately meant that at times the committee feltâand I think I speak for all members of the committeeâthat the Department of Defence claimed commercial and strategic sensitivities as a means of limiting open examination of the work that they were undertaking. I stress that the committee fully appreciated the need for confidentiality at some stages of some of the commercial dealings, but the public also has the right to know how public funds are being allocated.

To say that the information the committee was after was less than forthcoming is a magnified understatement. The Department of Defence spends about $3 billion a year on major projects. It is true to say that the committee has had a longstanding interest in Defence's management of major projects, as the chairman has said. I am sure, with the record that the defence department has had, that will continue in the future.

One of the largest concerns is the actual future of the JORN project. The final cost to the Australian taxpayer is still unclear. I think many members of the committee were shocked at the cavalier attitude to taxpayers' funds shown by various Commonwealth instrumentalities. There seemed to be an attitude from Defence that as long as Telstra or, as it was, Telecom carried the burden then it did not really matter to Defenceâin fact, the taxpayer was always going to pick up the bill. I think there should be a greater realisation of the total cost to the Commonwealth rather than to individual departments or instrumentalities.

The committee recognised the possible solutions that could come out in some of the key recommendations. One was obtaining managers with the right expertise for major acquisition projects. It appeared to us that, in many instances, the defence department used some of their project teams as burial grounds for people who were not considered good enough to be promoted.

We also thought in this instance that we should bring in non-defence experts for senior project positions, and particularly that there should be the establishment of a career structure in procurement and project management. Also, we felt it should be ensured that, in any future Commonwealth contracts and related subcontracts, access to intellectual property is clearly defined. There was quite a deal of debate during the hearings about access to intellectual property, and I am not quite sure whether we ever found out if the Commonwealth has any intellectual property in this project at all.

I think the best way for this sort of projectâand indeed any future defence projectâto operate is to learn from the mistakes that JORN has made since 1991 and include strong financial management of the project. The defence department needs to understand that it has to provide value for money if it is going to maintain the support of the Australian public. Given that this project alone has been in the making for over 20 years, the Australian taxpayer deserves nothing less.

I would like to thank the other speakers in this debate, the committee for the work undertaken, the committee members and those who gave evidence, even if the evidence was given reluctantly. Sometimes it was like extracting teeth to get some evidence out of some people, although I must say that it is probably one of the most fulsome inquiries I have been involved in but spread over the longest period of time. I commend this very important report to the House and hope that all honourable members will read it.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThe Jindalee operational radar network is a very important defence project. JORN, given its completion, promises to enhance Australia's security by providing an unparalleled wide area surveillance capacity. While JORN's full strategic significance is classified and could not be accurately assessed by the committee, an insight into the importance attached to it by the defence professionals is conveyed by the number of dollars committed to it. If JORN had been completed on budget and on time, it would have consumed eight per cent of total defence capital expenditure over six financial years.

speech.para: The goals of the Jindalee project were to have an over-the-horizon network in operation by 1997 at a target cost to the Department of Defence of $814 million for the prime contract, which would yield the prime contractor a profit of an undisclosed magnitude using an Australian prime contractor which would have a major ongoing defence role. Fundamentally, the story of JORN as disclosed by the JCPA's review is a story of substantial failure to date.

Regarding timing, on 13 June 1991 Telecom was awarded the contract to build JORN by mid-1997; a six-year design and construction timetable. The current best estimate for JORN's overall completion is September 2002 or December 2001âfour or five years, depending on which date you take, later than the original completion date. The phrase `best estimate' is used advisedly. There have been numerous reschedulings of JORN's completion date. To date none have been met.

Regarding price, Defence's original target price for the prime contract was $685 million. By April 1996, $657 million had been paid out. The actual price to Defence is now estimated to go to the ceiling price, which is now $902 million. Even accepting the mysteries of Defence's price escalation, Defence will end up paying tens of millions of dollars more for the project than the originally targeted price.

Telstra, far from making a profit, is projecting a loss of $606 million; a loss almost equivalent to the totality of the original target price. I think it is incumbent on me to say, given the disingenuousness of some of the testimony provided to the committee, that the extent of the projected loss may not have been disclosed, despite the committee's efforts, had the privatisation of Telstra not been in the offing.

Regarding the objective of engaging an Australian prime contractor in order to avoid dependence on overseas firms and create a long-term Australian prime contractor, Telstra, that prime contractor is now effectively reduced to paying the bills, and is getting out of defence contracting. The responsibility for delivering the project has passed to a US-Australian consortium.

In all, the Department of Defence chose a prime contractor that should not have been within a bull's roar of the project. Defence project management of a major project was deficient. There will be a massive loss to the Australian taxpayer passed on through Telstra.

Telstra has accepted that it should never have become involved in the project. Defence for its part have minimised the consequence of all of this by saying that, firstly, they will not be paying over the ceiling price and, secondly, they are happy to compromise on time in order to get the capability.

The facts, however, are that Australia will pay a higher price for JORN than was ever intended and probably a higher price than would have ever been countenanced. Australia will be denied the delivery of a substantial strategic asset for five years, and the strategic cost of the delay is not just that it increases the risk that the capability will not be available on the day it is needed; JORN is not a point in time asset. The real cost is that Australia is being denied the operation of a fundamental ongoing surveillance capacity for over half a decade.

The problems demonstrated by the committee's review of JORN are not a one-off case. Taken together with the problems, inefficiencies and inadequate management illustrated by the Auditor-General's reports on the ADF's food provisioning, health services and the army's presence in the north, it shows that vigilant monitoring of Defence expendi ture is an ongoing imperative. I would like to thank the secretariat of the JCPA, the members of the sectional committee and both chairmen of the JCPA who managed this review.

talk.start.para: âby leaveâThis report has been one of the most long running and detailed reports produced by the JCPA in the five years that I have been a member, the last two years as deputy chair. I think it has been one of the most interesting areas and issues to look into. But, having said that, I think that in the circumstances we have an area of some significance and that there has been in effect almost a fraud on the Australian people with respect to what has occurred around this project. The fact is that the role of Telstra and the role of the Department of Defence with respect to this particular project deserve probably even further scrutiny, and I worry, as I think other speakers have said, that down the track there may well have to be a son of JORN report on this issue.
âDaughter of JORN.

âOr daughter of JORN, because I suspect that the last page has not been written in this saga. This is a matter which ought be listed before the Main Committee in the future for further discussion. As we have agreed to keep our remarks brief at this stage, I will endeavour to do so. I would like to emphasise a couple of points, while I agree with what all previous speakers have said, because there has been a certain consistent strain coming through from this report.

speech.para: One issue that has concerned me for some time, relating to not only this particular issue but also others, is the role of Defence. When the JCPA examines issues relating to Defence, we continually find ourselves in a situation where Defence says, `Oh, well, we made a mistake; we are sorry, and we won't do it again.' The dog just keeps eating the homework. I for one am sick and tired of hearing about the dog eating the homework, but it seems to be something that will go on for many years to come. The operation of Defence is a very serious issue, particularly in project management. I do not think that Defence has shown that it has learnt the lessons over the years of this and other projects which have shown that there are ongoing problems with Defence and project management.

I think we can all be pleased that Telstra is a much better communications company than it is a Defence contractor. I wish it well with respect to phones and other systems of that nature and suggest that it think twice before ever entering this field againâas I am sure it will. If we were talking about Telstra share prices based on it being a Defence contractor, I do not think the government would be crowing quite the way they have been in recent times. The fact is that there is a range of issues which deserve further scrutiny. We also have this ongoing problem with Defence which has been there for many years. Attempts by governments of all persuasions have been made to remedy it, with some difficulty.

One of the other issues I would like to refer to at this stage is why it ended up like this. I guess the first point is what happened in the first place. The question has been asked by some about this contention: why were the basic constraints of this projectâthe Australian components to the overall bids and the technologyâsent across to local indigenous producers and companies? I make the point very clear that this, in the context of the times, was a position which was bipartisan, as is clearly shown by statements made around the time of the 1987 white paper by the then shadow minister for defence, the now Speaker, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

From that, the way that Defence operates as a decision making entity is something that also needs to be reviewed. It even goes beyond the question of project management. It is an issue that is of real concern. We are not talking about small amounts of money. Unfortunately, when you talk about project management in Defence going wrong, you are not talking about a few dollars; you are talking about millions and sometimes billions of dollars. When you make a mistake, boy, it is a big one.

I thank all those involved in the reportâthe secretariat and other members of the committeeâand congratulate them on the work that they have done. It has been a long time in its gestation, but that has been necessary because the difficulty has been getting the facts and holding them down. It has been a bit like chasing a rabbit with a fishing net.

What we have here now is as good as can be done in the circumstancesâgiven the recalcitrance of a number of witnesses and the difficulty of establishing the facts and maintaining those facts at a particular time. Like I have said, we have a report here that is worthy of consideration to a greater degree. But I will not be surprised if some time in the future I am standing here welcoming son of JORN.
