talk.start.para: âThe Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997 responds to several of the recommendations that came out of the reports of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on both the 1993 election and the 1996 election and also the 1995 report on redistributions.

speech.para: One of the features of the politics of the 1980s and 1990s is that the Liberal and National parties, after the 1984 election, were always within striking distance of Labor in terms of seats and votes. In fact, in the 1987 election, the Liberal and National parties outpolled Labor in primary votes. In the 1990 election, the Liberal and National parties outpolled Labor both on primary votes and also on two-party preferred terms. So the results of national elections are often determined by a small number of votes in several marginal seats. For example, part of my seat of Boothby used to be the old seat of Hawker, which I think the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus) won eight years ago today by 14 votes. Sometimes it can be very close.

Going back a bit further, there is the apocryphal and famous example of Jim Killen winning the seat of Moreton, which was the swing seat in the 1961 election, on Communist Party preferences, thereby being told by Robert Menziesâagain, apocryphalâ`Killen, you're magnificent.'

Also, in 1993, if 1,500 voters Australia-wide in just a certain number of marginal seats had changed their votes from Labor to the coalition, John Hewson would have been elected in that election. So it is important that we have an electoral system that has integrity and that rorting ballots is made as difficult as possible.

The subject of electoral fraud was considered by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in both its reports into the 1993 and 1996 elections. While it felt that there were no examples of fraud that had changed the results in any division, it did notice, for example, that following the 1996 election there were 302 cases of multiple or dual voting which could not be explained and which were referred to the Australian Federal Police. At the time of the report there had been three convictions.

In this bill, item 161 will amend subsection 339(1) of the act. Currently, the act provides that a person shall not wilfully vote more than once at the same election. As the Australian Electoral Commission has noted, the word `wilfully' makes obtaining prosecution very difficult. Item 161 will remove `wilfully' from the act. As previous speakers have mentioned, most of the amendments in this bill are minor technical amendments which respond to problems which were evident in the 1993 and 1996 elections. Most of them have bipartisan support and are uncontroversial.

Items 17 and 18 will increase the range of the average divisional enrolmentâthe size of seatsâfrom plus or minus two per cent to plus or minus 3Â½ per cent. That is to give more flexibility to the redistribution committee to consider things like physical features, communication and travel within the elector ate, as well as the elusive criterion of community of interests.

Increasing that range will allow more flexibility without undermining the principle of one vote, one value. I would sound a note of warning. Looking at the state elections of the late 1980s, one of the features was that often the conservative parties, the Liberal and National parties, got a majority of votes in two-party preferred, yet it was never enough to win the elections. The constitution actually does not provide for absolutely equal electorate size. That has been shown by the case of McGinty and Ors v. State of Western Australia 1996, Commonwealth Law Report 140. So one vote, one value, while we might expect it, is not entrenched in the constitution.

talk.start.para: âCertainly not in the Senate.

âI might mention, for the information of the member for Dobell, that in the 1989 state election John Olsen won 52 per cent of the two-party preferred vote, but it was not enough to win. In actual fact, it was well known that he probably needed something like 54 per cent of the two-party preferred vote to win. You might remember in the 1989 state election in Western Australia, Mr Deputy Speaker, that Peter Dowding was able to be returned with only 48 per cent of the two-party vote. The Liberal and National parties had 52 per cent of the two-party vote. Again, it was not enough to win.

speech.para: In the 1988 state election in Victoria, similarly, the Liberal and National parties outpolled Labor, but it just was not enough to win. While people remember gerrymanders in terms of the Queensland gerrymander, it is worth remembering that that was initially introduced by the Hanlon Labor government. In my own state of South Australia, while people would remember the unequal electorates of the Playford era, and that had been quite a controversial topic at the time and opposed by university student John Bannon in the 1960s, in actual fact, as many electoral scientists showed, the electoral advantage he had in terms of unequal electorate size and so on was actually just as powerful as the one that Playford had in the 1950s and 1960s.

Returning to the bill, there have been a number of sensible amendments previously to remove voters of unsound mind, for example, due to Alzheimer's disease, but the process has been excessively bureaucratic. The objection had to be lodged by an elector in the same division and $2 had to be paid as an objection fee. There is no good reason for this. The bill actually removes those two requirements; and that is a sensible improvement.

Also, regarding declared institutions, which are hospitals or nursing homes, the present rule under the Electoral Actâand not everyone is aware of thisâis that candidates cannot canvass in the declared institutions once the writ is issued. This does sometimes create problems because the declared institutions are not gazetted for some time after the return of the writ. An amendment in this bill will ban canvassing for five days before and also including the polling day, but it will allow it before that. So that will actually allow some canvassing in nursing homes.

Item 150, which relates to the sections in the Electoral Act which saw the gaoling of Albert Langer, will repeal subsection 329(3) of the Electoral Act which led to that gaoling. Albert Langer, you might remember, in 1996 was effectively advocating an optional preferential vote, to vote 1, 2 and then 3, 3, 3 and so on. Repealing this subsection will not allow optional preferential voting, but it will prevent anyone acting as a political martyr by advocating an optional preferential vote.

Going into the Electoral Act, section 240 prescribes full preferential voting. However, in the mid-1980s, section 270(2) was introduced to allow voters who missed a square or who repeated a number to have their vote counted. It was a safety net for people who did not fill out their ballot paper correctly but whose intention was quite clear. In the 1987 and 1990 federal elections, there were electors who encouraged an effective optional preferential vote by using that section 270. Before the 1993 election, section 329 of the Electoral Act was introduced. That made it an offence to distribute any material which undermined full preferential voting. In 1996, Albert Langer took out advertisements advocating how to vote for neither. The Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, in looking into the 1996 report, recommended repealing 270(2), 329(3) and 329Aâand that is all in this bill.

It is important to emphasise this because it was mentioned by the member for Lowe (Mr Zammit) last night and it was actually mentioned in the briefing given by the Department of the Parliamentary Library. Both the comments by the member for Lowe and the comments in the Department of the Parliamentary Library's brief are actually quite wrong. The brief is exactly the same as the comments by the member for Lowe. It says:
The result of this amendment is that optional preferential voting will still be valid and people will now be able to lobby others to vote in this fashion.

The first part of that statement is wrong. The sections in this act reinforce full preferential voting. Someone like Langer can advocate it, and if someone does it they will not be prosecuted. If anyone does a 1, 2, 3, 3, 3 vote, that will now be an informal vote; so full preferential voting has been reinforced in this bill. As I said before, this is a change in the practice since 1997 whereby there has been a safety net for electors who made a mistake. Just to emphasise this point, I note that last night during the second reading debate the member for Lowe stated:
The result of this amendment is that optional preferential voting will still be valid and people will now be able to lobby others to vote in a similar fashion.

The first part of that sentence is incorrect. The member for Lowe has proceeded on the assumption that subsection 329(3) is the only subsection to be repealedâthe one which dealt with the gaoling of Albert Langer. The amendments will also cause the repeal of section 270(2) and section 329A. Section 270(2), which has previously provided the safety net which has allowed for optional preferential voting, is no longer in the bill. A person could advocate an optional preferential vote but, if they do, that vote will be invalid. It is important that that is recorded in Hansard . I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: âThe opposition's approach to the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997 and to the report of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters on the 1996 election has ironically been summarised in the contribution of the member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou). He said that the changes are designed to improve a system which is amongst the very best in the world. Those comments are certainly amplified by the unanimous aspects of the report of the committee:

speech.para: 1.12 The basic strengths of the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (the Electoral Act) and its administration by the AEC were again demonstrated in 1996. It should be a matter of pride that some 11.3 million widely dispersed electors can have their votes recorded so efficiently, and that within a couple of hours of the close of polls they can be told which party is to form government. The continuing overseas interest in the AEC's services is also testimony to Australia's election systems.

That is the analysis that the opposition would make of Australia's electoral processes. We know that this bill is not controversial, but it is only one of a number of measures that will be a reaction to this report. Elements in the government pretend that there are major deficiencies and that there is evidence of corruption in the Australian political system. I have to say that very little evidence has been produced in the course of such an extensive report and in its consideration. I commend both chairmen, who were often very partisan, often very controversial. At the end of the day there was no evidence of these allegations. There was no evidence of mass rorting and no evidence that our system is in any way to be compared with those of Kenya, Sri Lanka or any other systems in which such allegations are made.

As other people have indicated earlier, there are very few controversies in this legislation. There is a proposed measure that in future we should increase the deposits, which have not moved since 1983. It would seem reasonable to most people that in the case of House of Representatives the deposit should move from $250 to $350; in the case of the Senate, from $500 to $700. In the 1996 election, 402 of the 908 House of Representatives candidates around Australia received less than four per cent of the vote; in similar fashion, 57 of the 85 Senate teams around this country also failed to get four per cent of the vote. It is quite reasonable therefore that we should try to discourage candidates who have minimal electoral support. Once again, I do not think there is any dispute around the place that there should be an enhanced requirement in regard to their obtaining signatures.

We know that the disabled's access to polling booths is very difficult because the AEC have to obtain premises from organisations they do not control. The provision hereâI gather it is already in Queensland legislationâfor disabled people who will face major difficulties in going into the polling booth to cast their vote to be facilitated outside the premises is, once again, non-controversial and quite reasonable.

The committee considered that there were quite onerous requirements on Australian citizens who went overseas for a period and could find themselves off the rolls despite a continuing interest in Australian politics. Once again, the committee agreed that they should not be burdened by unnecessary requirements. However, the committee was unanimous in its concern that it did not want a situation like that in the Cook Islands or Italy where people who have no contact or relationship with the country any longer can be flown in, in mass numbers, for election day. The committee's provision therefore tries to find balance. As has been indicated, there is very little controversy in these measures.

As for the way in which the poll shall be declared, as was said earlier, the removal of the word `wilfully' from the act will make it a lot easier to prove that someone is guilty of fraudulent conduct in the election, thus making it easier to gain a conviction. There is a large number of procedural aspects in this legislation on which there is no disagreement. However, there is a slight argument on the matter of overseas enrolments. I want to raise a few other aspects of the report and to touch on where this legislation is going. In the Economist of 8 February, which has wide readership within government ranks but probably not too many subscribers on our side of politics, there was a very interesting comment in an article entitled `Politicians for rent'. That article said:

Campaign-finance reform is a constant game of catch-up. Matters get out of hand; some curb is introduced; candidates find a way round it, or break it; and a new curb is erected further down the street. In this, America is no exception: most countries set limits on the role money plays in elections and many political scandals have had some connection with campaign finance . . . America's problems are nothing like as bad asâ
those of some othersâ

but all the same, in the new Congress, dozens of different clean-up bills are being introduced. Some are meant to tighten up laws that are being broken; others are meant to plug loopholes. And, on past experience, most are doomed.

We all know in the US a variety of measures have been introduced into the current Congress by Senator Biden and a number of other people. As was indicated by the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan)âonce again, that article is spot on about problems in this countryâit really is catch up. The current government has a very sorry record in regard to basically trying to exploit the effort by the legislature, the effort by the general public, to make sure money does not run politics.

In a previous experience an associated entity had to be created to try to close one of these loopholes. As was indicated by the member for Canberra, the opposition, hopefully with the support of other parties, will try to do something about these latest efforts in regard to the Greenfields Foundation whereby the purported measure this time is a loan of vast amounts of money to the Liberal Party. The AEC has indicated it will take two years to do something about thisâtwo years to investigate it properly to find out whether it is a loan or essentially a donation under other grounds.

Whilst there are a few nice provisions in this bill with regard to clauses 309.1 and 314AB relating to minor aspects of public finance in this country, it really does not do anything, quite understandably I guess, about the government's continuing failureâas that Economist article says, this is catch-up politicsâand the continuing struggle of the parliament. The member for Boothby (Dr Southcott) has indicated that the Economist is a bible, the Economist is a very reliable journal. He holds it up here today to say that he recognises what it says.

The point those opposite make quite reliably is that we do have a problem when the general public does not really understand where money is being sourced from and what favours can possibly be called up. We have had a leading indication of a major political issue in this country: aged care. Mr Moran has said to Mr Ruddock and a number of other members of parliament, `You owe. I was a major donor, and you have not delivered.' Mr Moran's donations were possibly public. That one is out there in the general community, but there are others that are concealed by the Greenfields Foundation and its predecessor, the Free Enterprise Foundation, whereby the current governmentâ

talk.start.para: âThe trade unions.

âThe member opposite talks about the trade unionsâonce again, not a very fortunate analogy because essentially there is no foundation that seeks to hide behind loans to the Labor Party of many millions of dollars.
âBut you just do their bidding.

âWe just do their biddingâthat is an interesting proposition. But a fact of life is that we have a major loophole here which this government is not doing anything about. Essentially, this government is about protecting that. As was indicated, an amendment will be moved in the upper house.

speech.para: One other matter I want to raise relates to subdivisional voting. I really do hope that in the legislation the government promises to introduce later something is done about the situation in the Northern Territory and Kalgoorlie. We have a proposition here. The government have argued in the course of discussing this report that they are going to bring back subdivisional voting; that, to counter the supposed alleged unproven corruption that this country faces in elections, they will introduce subdivisional voting.

Unfortunately, two electorates already have this. In one of them, the Northern Territory, we have one of the major travesties of justice in this country. Unlike the rest of Australia, the Northern Territory is divided into 25 subdivisions based on the territory electorates. The sad outcome of that is that large numbers of voters in that electorate are deprived on election day in this country of their right to have their vote counted. If they lived in Ballarat, Bendigo or Reid, essentially their votes would be counted.

An unfortunate reality is that that electorate has a significant Aboriginal population and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Electoral Information Service has been thrown out the doorâit has been deprived of funding and destroyed by this government. People living in that electorate have the other problem that, if they move across the road, half the time their votes are ruled out. If I moved from Guildford to Granville, my vote would still be counted, but people who move across Darwin or Alice Springs are basically deprived of having their vote counted.

It is interesting to note that in the whole of Australia only 39.3 per cent of provisional votes are rejected but in the 1996 elections in the Northern Territory over 65 per cent of provisional votes were rejected exactly because of the technicality of people moving from subdivision to subdivision. I was pleased that, despite our political differences, despite our partisan self-interest, the committee could come to the unanimous resolution which appears at paragraph 4.6 of its report:

Commonwealth electors should be treated in a uniform way throughout Australia. Until such time as the governments of the Commonwealth and the Northern Territory renegotiate the joint roll agreement, the Territory's subdivisions should be effectively suspended for federal elections.

That is a pretty accurate analysis of what should be done. It is up to this government to say that, regardless of how much so many voters basically having their votes wiped out on election dayâthis is despite their casting their votes properly like people around the rest of the countryâhelps them, these voters should not be deprived of a vote because of this technicality.

It is also interesting to note, when we talk about Aboriginals in this country, that the turnout in the rest of Australia at the last federal election was 95.8 per cent; in the Northern Territory it was only 89.1 per cent. That is an indication of why this authority, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Electoral Information Service, which the Electoral Commissioner went out of his way to basically defend and said that it has been doing a good job and went to bat for it very strongly with regard to its performanceâand we all know it is an independent authority that does not try to get involved in the political process and show any kind of partisanshipâis so important. But this government abolished it. Quite frankly, we are seeing that there is a need for it which is shown not only by the low turnout in the Northern Territory but also by the fact that people in that state have far fewer rights than the rest of Australia when it comes to voting.

This report is non-controversial. It represents those aspects of the committee's analysis of the 1996 elections, which we could all come to an agreement about. But, down the track, we will have proposals from the current government that will fundamentally change elections in this country. Under the guise of saying there is massive corruption, under the guise of saying that the AEC cannot control things, under the guise of saying that people are running around the place in every suburb in this country with nothing better to do than to put people down under false enrolments, they are going to totally change the electoral process in this country to make it more difficult for people to cast votes.

The government have come up with ideas, for example, that everyone should run around the place with ID cards on election day. If you are at Bondi Beach and you do not have your ID card on you, you have to go back to Penrith to get the card to cast a vote. They are saying that you have to vote in a very prescribed area, in a subdivision, a small area within the electoral. If you live at Guildford you will not be able to vote at Granville; if you live at Strathfield you will not be able to vote at Burwood.

This is what this government intends down the lineâto set up a series of processes, a series of hurdles, to deprive people of their rights, to make it difficult to vote, to make sure that those who are slightly less interested, slightly more apathetic than others do not cast a vote.

talk.start.para: âThe changes proposed by the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997 now before the House are numerous and many of them can be considered minor. They are changes, however, of an administrative nature which represents more than a refinement of procedures relating to the conduct of elections and referenda. The changes proposed here are indicative of this parliament's recognition of the evolving nature of political, economic, social and technological environments in which we find ourselves. Once assented to, they will attest to the parliament's willingness to respond to such environmental changes in a timely and most appropriate way. This is, indeed, precisely what we as elected representatives have been given the responsibility of doing on behalf of the citizens of Australia. After all, parliament is this country's legislature and we as parliamentarians are charged with legislating to legitimise socially desirable changes.

speech.para: It has been said in these rapidly changing times that the only constancy is change itself. Changes in political, social, economic and technological environments within our country inevitably impact upon our formal institutions. The institution of our democratic practices is not exempt from the need for change. If we were to ignore today's call for change to our electoral laws we would be saddled with a system that would become increasingly irrelevant and ineffectiveâan outdated vehicle for democracy. Whilst the original Greek or Athenian form of direct democracy was a fine chariot in its time not many would choose to ride in a chariot today. It could not compete with the technologically advanced, finely tuned machines that deliver fast, comfortable travel over the long haul. What we are about here today is constructing a more sophisticated, finely tuned electoral machine that will deliver speed, economy and satisfaction which is capable of taking us into the future.

Democracy is generally recognised as being born of ancient Greek traditions from around 500BC. Pericles, on his death bed, extolled its virtues by giving people self rule, free speech, universal citizenship and political power. Furthermore, it enshrined freedom and tolerance in private lives while creating public responsibility and obedience to law. This may have been the ancient Greek's intention, but reality fell a little short of this favourable depiction. Public works were accomplished through slavery, women were not considered citizens and therefore did not have the right to vote and free thinkers such as Socrates were put to death in such a democracy. Nevertheless, Athenian democracy introduced the concept of citizen self rule through direct and continuous participation of eligible citizens in legislative and judicial processes. There was a general assembly of all citizens, and a council of 500 elected members met every day. These 500 were selected by multiple methods and were paid for their services. A rotation system was in place which ensured every citizen took his turn on the council.

Although the system became unwieldy and fell into decline, democracy resurfaced in an evolved form after the revolutions in England, France and America. In place of direct democracy representative democracy was born. Liberal democracies took hold in the Western world, although democratic systems bore different characteristics in different countries. These differences reflected each country's unique history, culture and values. It also was indicative of varying interpretations of the word democracy.

The most readily recognisable definition of democracy is Abraham Lincoln's given in his `four score and seven years ago' Gettysburg addressâthat is, `government of the people, by the people, for the people'. This definition can be loosely interpreted. The so-called social democracies may claim to provide government of, by and for their people, but they are vastly different beasts from the Liberal democracies. Liberal democracies read into the definition of democracy Liberal concepts of individual freedom, freedom of opportunity, protection of private property, the rule of law and limited government. This is the case in Australia where we are fortunate indeed to have strong Liberal tradition embed ded in our history, our culture and our political system.

In Australia over time we have interpreted democracy variously. Like Greece, citizenship was not universal in our original democratic framework. Women and Aborigines were declined the vote and did not obtain it until 1908 and 1967 respectively. The fact that changes were made extending the franchise is a reflection of the change of attitudes. Likewise, changes have been made to many elements in our electoral lawsâincluding electoral boundaries, the number of elected representatives and the voting system itself. A Liberal democratic tradition pervades not only our political culture but also our electoral system. It adapts the system as needs arise and political opinions dictate.

As I said earlier, we as parliamentarians are charged with legislating to legitimise desirable change. There are a number of changes proposed by this bill that have arisen through the need for public demand and through the opportunities made available through technology. These are changes that have been well researched and recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in its report on the conduct of the 1993 federal election, the report on electoral redistribution and the report on the conduct of the 1996 federal election.

There has been extensive research on the effectiveness and relevance of our electoral practices. There has also been widespread consultation. This research and consultation have given rise to the recommendations contained in the bill currently before the House, and I believe those recommendations deserve bipartisan support.

I would like to highlight the links between a number of the bill's provisions and some of the changes in our social, political, technological and economic environments that have prompted this legislative response. We have recognised that there is a social benefit to be gained through the proposed amendment that allows the gender of electors to be disclosed for the purpose of approved medical health research and public health screening surveys. This trend towards public screenings has gained widespread public approval. Indeed, there is now an expectation that services of this nature be provided. This is largely due to the success rates associated with advanced methods of early detection of a number of conditions such as breast cancer. We believe that disclosure of the gender of electors for approved purposes is in the interests of the community, and we have responded with this amendment.

A social concern that we have recognised is the inconvenience imposed on some members of our community through bureaucratic red tape associated with enrolment objection processes. I refer here to the close relatives and friends of electors of unsound mind. Where these friends or relatives apply for the elector's removal from the roll, an unnecessarily long objection process currently has to be gone through, including payment of an objection deposit. We have identified that this is an unjust and inequitable imposition on carers and a hindrance to their individual freedom. These carers are people whom society should value and encourage in their compassionate role. They should not be put through an obstacle course in their endeavours to assist the disabled.

This bill improves the objection process to allow relatives and friends who do not live in the same subdivision as the elector to make application for removal from the roll based on medical advice and without payment of an objection deposit. It is a Liberal tradition to keep government out of the private lives of individuals wherever possible. This amendment is consistent with that tradition.

The next amendment I refer to is also one derived from the basic Liberal traditionâprotection of private lives. John Stuart Mill, who is often regarded as the father of modern liberalism, in his essay On Liberty, identified that there were public and private spheres in every individual's life and that there was no justification for government to intervene in individuals' private spheres unless harm to others was being caused.

As Liberals, we find it necessary to make an amendment to the current laws to ensure that personal details of people who specifically nominate to be recorded on the electoral roll as silent electors will not be disclosed to persons inspecting applications for postal votes. Clearly, this protection of individual privacy is expected by society in a Liberal democracy today and causes no harm whatsoever to others. Therefore, we strongly advocate the inclusion of this socio-political amendment to our electoral laws.

This bill also addresses the social demand for change to disallow canvassing in and around hospitals that are polling places on polling day and in special hospitals during the five days before, and including, polling day. Confusion regarding hospital status as special hospitals will be eliminated because once hospitals are gazetted, they will remain so on an ongoing basis unless abolished by gazettal.

Technological advances have given rise to the possibility of saving time and money in the election process. It is incumbent upon us to be prudent economic managers, making savings to the community where possible and where appropriate. As progressive Liberals, we propose that amendments be made to current electoral laws to introduce relevant technology that will allow the Australian Electoral Commission the option to use an up-to-date method of security printing of the ballot papers instead of using watermark ballot papers. Considerable savings will be achieved in storage and production costs as a result.

We also propose to enable the Australian Electoral Commission to conduct Senate scrutiny of all `below the line' votes using a computer process. In view of the fact that it is possible that some Senate election papers will be almost a metre long at the next election, this is most certainly a timely amendment that will save time and error in scrutineering. As the report on the 1996 federal election says, it `ought to be implemented before the next federal election'.

We propose in this bill some political amendments that one would expect to be initiated by a Liberal government such as this one with a strong mandate from the people. I refer to the proposed amendment regarding electoral redistributions. This government is committed to openness and accountability and therefore recommends that comments and objections in relation to redistributions are made available for public scrutiny. It also recommends that the tight constraints on electoral variations between electorates be relaxed to allow for the community of interest factors to be considered. Liberals acknowledge that not all communities are identicalâthat the interests of people within boundaries are at least as important as the numerical statistics.

My final comment is with respect to the bill's provision for increasing from six to 50 the number of signatures required in support of a nomination by a candidate not endorsed by a registered political party. Registered political parties nominating members are required to have at least 500 members. We agree with the 1996 federal election report that a candidate for the Senate who is not able to attract 50 signatures within a division, let alone a state or a territory, would have no hope of election. Potential candidates must therefore be required to demonstrate at least a modest level of support.

The abovementioned proposed amendments to our democratic system are strongly characteristic of a Liberal democracy. They are what the people of Australia demand. I would like to think that the changes proposed by this bill have bipartisan support, because they make good sense. Questions have been raised about what change will create the most effective vehicle for democracy in our country. Some of those questions are answered by the proposed amendments contained in the Electoral and Reform Amendment Bill 1997 before the House today.

I commend the bill to the House. It is one that will make our electoral system more efficient, user friendly and economical and will serve us well into the future. By supporting this bill, parliament will demonstrate its commitment to adapting to one of our most important institutionsâour democratic institutionâto give it relevance and effectiveness in today's circumstances.

talk.start.para: âIf one listened very closely to the member for Boothby (Dr Southcott) earlier in this debate on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997 , and to other comments that have been previously been made by members of the coalition, they almost made it. They almost made it in 1993. They almost made it in 1990. They would have been in government if it had not been for problems within the electoral system that Australia currently has. They almost made it, and they would have made it, if it were not for a few votes in a few electoratesâand that is why they lost.

speech.para: Given that that attitude is not just unique to the member for Boothby but shared by a number of people in the coalition, it is not surprising that they thought the 13 years they spent in opposition was not a direct result of the positions that they took, the issues that they argued and the fact that they could not convince the electorate at large. There were always the grand excuses, which essentially came down to the fact that they did not get enough seats, and they did not get enough seats because there were just a few people who went the wrong way.

The most significant and most controversial matters within the 1996 federal election report that has been produced by the Joint Committee on Electoral Matters will come in a later bill. The key thing we expect to be debated in that later bill will in fact be whether or not there should be voluntary voting. If we link that question to what was intoned by the member for Boothby earlier today, and what other members have concentrated on previously, they almost would have made it in 1990 or 1993 but they were done out because of deficiencies in the system, but one way to fix that would be to do away with compulsory voting, which has been here since 1924, and replace it with voluntary voting.

I suspect that the reason we have not got it in this bill and we will be dealing with it in a later one is that a number of people within the coalition actually argue that compulsory voting is important and should be retained. I have been pleased previouslyânot only here within this debateâto read one of the papers the member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou) put out on this whole issue of compulsory versus voluntary voting. If he is being joined by others, I expect that we will not deal with that issue directly here. In at least a good part of the coalitionâbut not in the members who brought down this majority reportâthere is a strong sense that the benefits in the electoral system that we have, which the member for Kooyong pointed out, have been progressively improved since 1901 and that those benefits should not be simply thrown away.

I will return to that when we actually debate the bill, if the government brings that before the House. But, at this point, I want to point out my utter, total and strong opposition to the notion that we should move from compulsory to voluntary voting. That path has been prefigured by what happened in the elections for the Constitutional Convention. Compulsory voting has stood us well. It is not just a right but a duty of the citizens of this country. It is a duty that should be maintained into the future if we are to have a completely viable democracyâone in which people exercise their duties and responsibilities and not simply their rights.

I want to speak about a number of the provisions in this bill before going to some wider matters that the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) and other speakers dealt with as to what is not, and should be as a matter of urgency, in this bill in regard to political funding. I first wish to deal with a concern I have in regard to the allowable range between electorates when one has a redistribution. In the current act the allowable range is from 98 per cent to 102 per cent. So an electorate may be two per cent below or two per cent above the quota that has been struck. This has not always been the case. In the past in the Commonwealth we have had a situation where there has been an extremely wide variation in the numbers of people in different seats. Indeed, at state levelâand particularly in Queenslandâthere was an electoral system which was completely and utterly distorted in terms of the number of people in country seats as against the number of people in city seats.

What Labor did when it was in government, in bringing in the changes it made to the Electoral Act to ensure that there would be only a two per cent variation above or below, was to get as close as possible to the notion of one vote, one value. It is important to recognise that, in the provisions of this bill which seek to change that variation, instead of the two per cent either way, it is a question of 3Â½ per cent either way. So, where the quota is struck for a House of Representatives seat, this bill, when it goes through, will have 96Â½ per cent as the lower level and 103Â½ per cent as the upper level.

According to the background paper produced by the Department of the Parliamentary Library, this was the `most contentious issue' in the inquiry on these matters. It was contentious, I think, in two areas. The core one, as outlined in this background paper, and also as a result of the arguments put by a number of people on this particular matter, is that instead of just the numbers determining what happens when redistributions take placeâthose numbers currently, they argued, are too strictâyou need to do two things: firstly, you need to expand the percentage of variation from the quota that was struck from two per cent either way to 3Â½ either way and, secondly, that the redistribution commissioners should look to the existing boundaries as an important and central consideration and flip it around to use the general community of interest provisions as more important considerations.

What is the source of this? Why is it important and necessaryâaccording to this committee and in this billâto so expand the relevant range? It goes to what the member for Boothby was speaking about: the fact that the coalition just missed out in 1990 and 1993 and that they would have won if they had had more people in those marginal electorates. By increasing the range between seats from two per cent either way to 3Â½ per cent either way the coalition members of this committee think that they can embed themselves in marginal electorates and gain electorally as a result of that.

If you look at the comments that have been made at that committee's hearings, that stands up as a reasonable surmise. They talked about communities of interest and holding those together and there being greater flexibility. I quote from the background paper at page 2:
The 2% range did not, according to the proponents of change, allow any flexibility and was all about number-crunching.

The number crunching was about bringing, as far as possible, one vote, one value into the electoral system. From all I have seen throughout the coalition's periods in and out of office they have never been happy with the proposal that we should get as close as possible to one vote, one value. Hence the rationales for why they lost; hence this provision within this bill that the range should be increased and that the community of interest provisions be made broader.

The second thing I wish to deal with is the question of the relationship of these particular provisions to the Privacy Act 1988 and how that Privacy Act should be amended in order to take account of what is provided in this bill. At item 38 there is a recommendation that the Electoral Commission should:

. . . provide in electronic form, extracts of the electoral roll (including the sex of electors) to individuals or organisations conducting medical research or running health screening programs, Senators and Members and to registered political parties.

For all those last groups, that information is already provided to our electorate offices and to registered political parties. It is also provided to Commonwealth departments. But all of those entities are covered by the fact that this is information taken in by a government entity, the Australian Electoral Commission, and provided under strict conditions that directly relate to the Privacy Act 1988.

The recommendation in this bill that information in electronic form should be given to private medical research groups or to those running health screening programs would seem to be on the face of it a reasonable thing to do because people may have their health looked after better and they may be able to access that information for the benefit of individuals. Currently there is absolutely no control whatsoever under the Privacy Act 1988 in relation to those private companies which would be in receipt of that information. There is no control except in general guidelines and no real penalty for on-selling of that information to other organisations. The strict controls that are currently there for government institutions and registered political parties are there to retain the privacy of individuals who give that information to the Electoral Commission. Unless amendments to the Privacy Act are made, this is a proposition that opens up the prospect of individuals' privacy being utterly hampered as a result of this.

I wish to conclude my remarks in relation to these provisions and this bill by referring to what should be in it and what the member for Canberra alluded to in his speech. The relevant minister here is the Special Minister of State, Senator Minchin. On 9 March 1998, as reported in the Canberra Times, Senator Minchin indicated that he had refused to disclose details of a shadowy organisation which the federal opposition had claimed was being used by the coalition to circumvent rules for declaring political donations. This was, in fact, the Greenfields Foundation, which was the stepchild of the Free Enterprise Foundation, which had previously been used to funnel moneys into the Liberal Party of Australia. Senator Minchin said, very interestingly:
The Electoral Commission made it clear in evidence that it saw nothing improper about this loan.

He then went on to argue that there was nothing wrong with it, there were no problems and that the Electoral Commission really had no interest whatsoever in pursuing this matter much further. He said to the journalist from the Canberra Times , `Don't ask me any more about this. Go and talk to the Liberal Party or someone else.'

As indicated only three days later in an article in the Australian by Dennis Shanahan, the Australian Electoral Commission did not have that point of view. The Australian Electoral Commission are in fact seeking tough new powers to close loopholes and end confusion about the sources of millions of dollars in political donations which they claim are undermining the public disclosure system. Rather than having no problem with this schemeâthis latest scam from the Liberal Party of Australia, as the member for Canberra indicatedâthe Electoral Commission are asking that this problem be fixed. They say that they cannot demand that the Greenfields Foundation disclose to them the information they need in order to determine whether this organisation is an associated entity. They are in a position where they require this parliament to take speedy action to close the loophole. But we have seen nothing in the first instance in this bill which is non-controversial.

This is the first opportunity the government has had to put its cards on the table in relation to this matter. Have they taken action in relation to closing that loophole that the Greenfields Foundation is using? The answer is no. Is it likely that they will take action in the future to do that, given that they have not taken it in the first instance? I would argue again that the answer is most probably no. We have a commission arguing that it is not in a position to effectively enforce the electoral laws of this country in relation to this scheme where, instead of donations to the Liberal Party of Australia being covered by the Free Enterprise Foundation as in the past, a loan is made to the Greenfields Foundation, as this scam has it, and where, as the member for Canberra pointed out, there are direct directorial interconnections, post office box interconnections and phone number connections between those two organisations, the Free Enterprise Foundation and the Greenfields Foundation.

What has the federal government done in relation to this matter, the fact that, I think, $4.6 million has been loaned to the Liberal Party of Australia from the Greenfields Foundation and the Electoral Commission is not in a position to determine whether or not that is an associated entity? They have done nothing, and I expect that they will do nothing, because, whilst every member of the coalition has argued here that the electoral system is important and should be protected, we have yet another direct example of two things. First, the letter of the law for the coalition government will be skipped around and other vehicles will be found to subvert the provisions that are in those laws in regard to funding of its political processes.

The second thing is that there is no strong and direct commitment from the coalition government, apart from a few of its members, to an electoral system that is utterly and absolutely and straightforwardly fair. That is why they have moved to increase the range from two per cent to 3Â½ per cent, because they think it is just number crunching to get close to one vote, one value. They have no concern about that except to expand the range and attempt to make sure that that range is expanded not just for the purposes of ensuring community of interest but because they are convinced that they should have won in 1990 and they should have won in 1993.

This bill is largely non-controversial, firstly, because the controversial provisions have been left out for another bill because the coalition government cannot decide itself whether to take the step that was recommended by the government majority on their committee to propose the end of compulsory voting and its substitution by voluntary voting. Thankfully, there are still some people in the coalition who actually believe in compulsory voting, such as the member for Kooyong, and who are arguing forcefully that an electoral system which we have had operating since 1901 all up, and compulsory voting since 1924, is an absolutely world standard system. It can be improved, it can be adjusted, it can be moderated and it can be amended, and that has been done in the past.

The second thing is that, where they have not made a decision to run those controversial matters here, they should be utterly condemned for maintaining a loophole in the existing system in relation to the Greenfields Foundation. That system should have been fixed straight away. Contrary to the argument put forward by Senator Minchin that the Electoral Commission had no real concern about the loan, it is absolutely apparent in that article of 12 March that the commissioners are concerned, that they are in a position where they cannot act as a result of the situation of the current legislation and accordingly they have asked the minister, they are asking the parliament and they have asked the committees to take precipitate action to end this rort, to close that loophole and to ensure that the validity, importance and strength of our Electoral Commission is assured.

talk.start.para: âin replyâI wish to thank all members who have contributed to this debate on the Electoral and Referendum Amendment Bill 1997 . As I pointed out in the opening of the debate in December of last year, this bill contains a number of technical amendments to the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the Referendum (Machinery Provisions) Act. Many of those amendments, as has been pointed out by a number of those who have contributed to the debate, were recommended by the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters in its 1993 federal election report, its 1996 federal election report or its 1995 report on electoral redistributions. In the main, the matters contained in this bill result from those recommendations and they have received support from all parties. They have received that support either in the electoral matters committee or in the course of this debate. I am thankful for that. There was, of course, a debate in the previous parliament on some amendments at that stage which, as I understand it, did not reach conclusion before the parliament itself was dissolved.

speech.para: It is worthy of note that the Australian Electoral Commission has estimated that none of the amendments to the bill will give rise to additional costs and in fact two will provide some savings. That, of course, is always of interest to a finance minister. The amendment relating to alternative printing arrangements for ballot papers will give rise to estimated savings of some $800,000 over a three-year parliamentary term, and computerisation of the Senate scrutiny will provide estimated savings of $300,000 at each Senate election. In addition, the computerised Senate scrutiny will reduce the time taken to distribute preferences of Senate ballot papers, and all parliamentarians, I guess particularly those from the other place, become very frustrated with the time that is taken to resolve the Senate ballot after any election. A computerised system of scrutiny was successfully used in the Constitutional Convention election and in the 1997 election for the Legislative Council in South Australia. So it has been proven in a couple of instances and it will certainly lead to a more efficient process and a quicker outcome for that particular house.

Members would be aware of press articles in recent days which speculate on the government's position regarding issues of electoral reform that were recommended by the electoral matters committee in its 1996 federal election report, such as `Truth in political advertising', `Raising the threshold for tax deductibility of political donations', `Measures to strengthen the integrity of the enrolment and voting process', and so forth. The government is considering these more complex issues, and some of these, of course, are quite contentious. I assure honourable members that the government will address them as part of its formal response to that committee. However, the matters that are now before us in the form of this amendment bill are not controversial, and I note that all members who have contributed to the debate agree that the amendments are not controversial and those amendments are supported.

I note the intention of the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) to move an amendment to item 48 with respect to overseas elector provisions. Item 48 provides a mechanism for eligible persons who are overseas or who have been so for up to two years to enrol without first establishing a residency qualification in Australia, as is now required. I also note that the honourable member for Canberra indicated that the amendment does not fully implement the recommendation of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters. I am advised that the relevant recommendation of the report is not clear and, subsequently, further advice was sought from the committee as to its intention. The advice of the committee was that the period for allowing enrolment while overseas was to be for a period of two years, and the amendment was drafted accordingly. However, the government is amenable to extending this period to six years, as is proposed by the opposition. I do indicate, however, that we would like to have a little more time because there is a technical problem with this which perhaps I will deal with when we get to the consideration in detail stage.

I also foreshadowed an amendment to the bill which has been circulated and which the government intends moving at the appropriate time. That amendment will enable postal vote applications to be incorporated into campaign material sent to voters. My understanding is that that is acceptable to the opposition.

Most of the members opposite in making their contribution made some comments with regard to allegations with respect to loopholes in the disclosure provisions covering associated entities. There is nothing at this time to suggest that there is any loophole in the disclosure provisions. Where a loan is made to a political party on commercial grounds from whatever source, there is no financial benefit being derived. However, if a loan is made on favourable, non-commercial grounds, then the lender may well fall within the Electoral Act's definition of an associated entity and may be required to furnish comprehensive disclosure returns to the Australian Electoral Commission. I can assure honourable members that evidence provided in respect of the Greenfields Foundationâto which I note honourable members have made referenceâclearly indicates that there is a commercial basis for that, and the Electoral Commission has no reason to doubt from information provided anything to the contrary.
I again thank all honourable members for their contributions and commend this amendment bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
