talk.start.para: âThe Labor Party will be opposing this new accommodation charge that is being imposed by the Howard government on nursing home residents. It is yet another charge being imposed on the frail elderly of this country. It seeks to bring about a user pays system for nursing home careâwhich Labor views as essential health careâfor older Australians.

speech.para: Many people must be wondering why it is that we are here tonight debating this bill. In November last year, I am sure that all older Australians in particular will recall, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) did not come into the parliament but went on that very well watched program, A Current Affair. He went on that program to announce that the government finally realised that people would have to sell their homes to pay an accommodation bond; so he said that the accommodation bonds would be abolished. In their place he saidâand this is last Novemberâthat the government would introduce an accommodation charge.

For days it was unclear how much this charge would be. At first he said it was going to be in the order of $4,000. Then it was going to be an average of $4,000. Then it was to be capped between $7,000 and $10,000. And finally it was to be `capped' at $4,380, or half this amount for those with smaller assets. The level of assets and the level of fees to be paid has continued, in fact, to fluctuate right up until late February this year.

On 6 and 7 November last year, regulations were put in place that were meant to set the level of this new accommodation charge. When the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) returns to the chamber to respond to the second reading stage of this debate, I would like to ask him a number of questions about these regulations. I would like him particularly to table the regulations that gave the power to the government to raise this fee at that time, being from 6 November, because I have grave doubts about whether or not the government has had the legal right to make these accommodation charges. What I would like from the minister is a direct answer to the question: is that why we are debating this bill? Perhaps the next speaker would like to help the House answer this question: are we debating this bill here tonight because the government is concerned about the legality of the charges that have been in place since 6 November?

It is a very serious matter that we are debating here tonight. If the government has any legal advice or uncertainty about whether or not these charges should have been levied in the way they were from 6 November until whenever it will be that this bill that we are debating tonight comes into force, we would like to see that legal advice. More importantly, elderly people in nursing homes who have paid this fee would like to see that advice.

On 6 November the government through the user rights principles amendments set a maximum amount of $1 for an accommodation bond. This is the method they used to introduce this new notion of an accommodation charge. First of all, they set the accommodation bond at $1. They also introduced this new notion of a capped bond of $6 and $12. That happened on 6 November. On 7 November they made some additional points about the maximum daily amountâwe get the word `daily' introduced here. The word `daily' was not used on 6 November. On 6 November from that regulation it certainly is not clear that this capped bond was to be charged daily.

I would like to know how the minister defines a capped bond being a daily accommodation charge. If we look at the definitions in the original act, the Aged Care Act 1997, we go to the definition section and look at the definition of an accommodation bond, it states:
An accommodation bond in relation to a person means an amount of money paid or payable to an approved provider by the person for the person's entry to a residential care service . . .
Over the page under the definition of entry it states:
Entry in relation to a person and an aged care service means the commencement of the provision of care to the person through that aged care service.

That does not seem to me to be the same thing as a daily accommodation charge. As I said, we would be pleased to see how it is that the government has used these provisions of the act to set this new daily charge.

I notice that two weeks ago on 4 March another amendment was put through to the residential care subsidy principles. On that day, 4 March this year, an accommodation charge was finally defined. I wonder what went on in between. It seems to be the case that the user rights principles amendments that were put in place on 6 November last year tried to use the accommodation bond section of the Aged Care Act to set the accommodation charge to a maximum of $6 and $12 a day.

It is the case that section 57-12 of the act permits the setting of a maximum amount for a bond in the user rights principles and to overcome the maximum daily amount of residents' fees restrictions that exist in section 58-1 of the act it seems to us to be the case that the government is using part 5 section 23.82 of the user rights principles to specify an amount to be added to the daily amount of the residents' fees. But an accommodation bond, according to the user rights principles, can only be paid by lump sum, periodic payment or a combination of lump sum and periodic payment. It is later specified that the frequency of periodic payment cannot be more often than weekly.

As the accommodation charge is a daily charge, and therefore not an accommodation bond lump sum, it must be a periodic payment. But according to the act the frequency cannot be more than weekly. So our question is: if it is neither a lump sum nor a periodic payment it cannot be a bond. If it is not a bond, it seems to us there may not be any legal basis on which the government has introduced it. We are extremely concerned about what is going on. I ask the minister again: is this why we are debating this legislation tonight? Is it because the regulations made last year do not give the power to the government to raise those charges?

Labor will be opposing this accommodation charge of $4,380 a year or $12 a day which has replaced the iniquitous uncapped accommodation bond. As I am sure most members of the public are well aware by now, from Labor's point of view access to nursing home care should be on the basis of people's health care needs, not on the basis of how much a person has to pay. This new nursing home charge has been justified by the government as an essential step in meeting the capital needs of nursing homes and for preparing the ground for what the minister likes to call the tidal wave of older Australians that are apparently likely to need nursing home care in the future. But the real reason that all older Australians now know is behind the introduction of this government's new charges for nursing home fees is that this government slashed $500 million from the aged care budget in 1996.

The economic underpinning of this legislationâthe resource that the government hoped to tap after taking $500 million out of the aged care budgetâwas and still is the family home and savings of older Australians. Even though we have had so many backflips, so many backdowns and so many changes from this Prime Minister about nursing home care, it is still the case that the family home remains in the nursing home assets test.

New nursing home residents have been told that they can pay the accommodation charge by a range of different options. They can rent their homes or mortgage their homes, which is not a very attractive option to somebody in their nineties who has spent 50 years paying off their home and, needing to go into a nursing home, is told by this Prime Minister, `Go out and get another mortgage on your home.' The final option, one which the government does not like to give too much attention toânevertheless, it is still a very real option for most peopleâis selling their homes. The reality is that selling your home is still a very real option.
The Australian Catholic Health Care Association, in their journal, said:
The annual fee, or accommodation charge, is nothing more than a wolf in sheep's clothing. Selling their home will be the only option for many consumers.

Just last week the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants Federation, in a letter to the minister, said that a full or part pensioner will have no option but to sell their home. More than 70 per cent of people who go into nursing homes are full pensioners. They have little more than their pension. They have just one asset: their family home.

The other option put forward by the Prime Minister, which equally, along with selling and mortgaging your home, is not getting too much of a response, is that the elderly people needing to go into nursing homes should ask their families for the money. How many families around Australia have a spare $4,380 every year for five years to pay for the nursing home care of their elderly relatives because this government took $500 million out of nursing homes? People do not have that sort of money. It shows how out of touch this government and this Prime Minister are.

While the maximum charge is now set at $4,380, where is the guarantee that it will stay at this level? The minister wrote a letter to the Prime Minister last year, which we happen to have a copy of, saying:
Cabinet discussed this issueâ
That is, the maximum level of the chargeâ
and agreed a cap of $5,500 on 17 November.

This was after the regulations had set the levelâseemingly; that now seems to be in some doubtâat $4,380. The implication in the letter is: even though we set it at $5,500, we will leave it at $4,380âand here I quoteâ`to avoid raising community concern'. That is what the letter says from the minister to the Prime Minister.

We have to remember that all this was going on in the context of the Prime Minister's extraordinary backflip on accommodation bonds. The government had become totally panicked by community outrage. That is what it was about: community outrage about the way in which this government has been treating older Australians. So we have to look at this letter from the Minister for Family Services to the Prime Minister in this context.

While it obviously was the case that the government was very concerned `to avoid raising community concern', it was also equally determined to make older Australians pay for their nursing home care. Having taken $500 million out of the aged care budget, another $500 million had to come from somewhere.

Even though the Prime Minister had appeared on A Current Affair saying, `You will not have to sell your homes anymore,' what has remained the case is that older Australians will have to make up that $500 million. Those older Australians are to continue to be the source of that funding. Because it is the case that most elderly people have only the pension and generally have only one assetâthat is, their homeâwe all know now what the source of the money is going to be.
We are concerned about another statement that is in this letter from the minister to the Prime Minister. It says:
. . . the existing cap of $4,380 should remain pending a more detailed analysis of the industry's capital needs.

What are the industry's capital needs? In asking this question, it is very important to remember that, if it is the case that the industry's capital needs are not going to be met by the amount of money that is currently being taken from older people, what we are going to see is a move to increase the accommodation charge.

It is the case that nursing home providers have constantly told this government that this is simply not the way to go about upgrading nursing homes, that they cannot upgrade their nursing homes on the basis of the accommodation charge alone. We have here press releases from all the different organisations representing the different types of nursing homes and their consumers in this country.
On 27 February the Catholic, Anglican, Baptist and Uniting churches said:

. . . the present capital funding arrangements are totally unsatisfactory. The continued lack of resolve by the Government to restore its portion of the capital budget has left the residential sector stranded.
`Stranded' is what the church groups had to say. The National Association of Nursing Homes and Private Hospitals had this to say:
Under the present arrangements while some nursing homes will be able to achieve building quality by the year 2001, many others requiring substantial upgrading or rebuilding will not.

The private for-profit providers have been in open conflictâin fact, threatening legal action with the governmentâabout the issue of additional recurrent funding since the changes were introduced on 6 November. This funding was given to provide nursing homes the capacity to borrow larger amounts to pay for upgrades. But, under the new legislation, the government demanded that providers choose to take either the additional recurrent funding or the bonds.

As the additional recurrent funding was for past upgrades and the accommodation bonds or charges were supposed to be for future upgrades, the providers felt it was reasonable that they have access to both. The minister continues to fail to see the logic of this argument and so the capital upgrade problem continues to become that much greater. The providers of nursing home care in this country, I would have to say, have become so frustrated over this issue that they feel they are being put in a complete holding pattern by this government, being fobbed off until after the election, when goodness knows what will happen. An accounting body, Bentley's Chartered Accountants, came out with a statement on this in December last year. They said in a press release:
. . . the survey highlights the problems facing the Howard Government on Aged Care reform and underlines the need for urgent measures to be taken on funding improvements.

They have three reality checks, and I will read the first one: Reality Check 1: only 25% of Nursing Homes and 17.5% of Hostels believe they have funded policies for the replacement of their buildings!

A very serious state of affairs. The Council on the Ageing, an organisation that actually represents consumers of aged care services, said in December last year, after all these changes had taken place:
COTA has always argued that the Government should pay for current upgrading needs before fees and charges are applied to new residents.
They go on to say:
The $20 millionâ
which the government has announcedâ
is a start but we think it is not nearly enough and we will be seeking further funding from the next federal budget.

The Council on the Ageing release raises this issue of the $20 million. It was referred to in the release announced by the Minister for Family Services last December. It was supposed to be for nursing homes that needed urgent capital upgrades. What everybody would like to know is where is the $20 million? When will it be allocated? Who will get it?

The most telling evidence of the inadequacy of capital provision comes from a survey carried out by the Uniting Church, the largest supplier of residential aged care in Australia. This survey showed that in the last six years the church had spent an average of between $3 million and $13 million every five months on new hostel and nursing home development or on major refurbishment. In the last five months, since the implementation of the government's appalling aged care legislation, not one cent has been spent. The money is simply not provided for in the legislation. John Ireland, the President of Aged Care Australia, is quoted in the February edition of Australian Health and Aged Care Journal as saying:
I predict there will be further imposts on consumersâ
and this is the critical issue because, in the end, it is the elderly people of Australia that this Howard government is going to take the money fromâ
because, at the end of the day, a maximum charge of $4360â
he says $4,360 but it is actually $4,380â
just isn't enough.
The article goes on to say:
Ireland is calling for urgent recognition of the need for "further tinkering at the edges".

John Ireland is on the minister's new technical reference group so we should be able to give some credence to his prediction that elderly Australians are going to be paying more. Despite this almost universal condemnation of the adequacy of the current capital funding arrangements, it is obvious from the government's total silence in response to all these calls that the minister and this government intend to do absolutely nothing about the needs of nursing home residents in this countryâcertainly not until the election. What we have to sayâand what I know that all older Australians, in particular, are saying to meâis: given what they have done, what on earth will they do next? If they do not fix this problem after the election and, by some misfortune, they get elected again, what on earth will they do next to older Australians?

Last November we had all of the main not-for-profit providers meeting with the minister on the subject of capital needs. They thought they had reached agreement that they would spend some timeâeight weeks, I understandâactually calculating their exact needs. They wrote formally to the minister on 20 November letting him know what they intended to do. Nearly four months later the minister has yet to respond. As I said, what on earth can older Australians and their families draw from this? There is absolute certainty that nursing homes will get none of the capital that they need to upgrade from this government and that once the election has been held and, as I said, if we do find that this government is re-elected, the accommodation charge will certainly go up. People who need nursing home care will be paying more for essential health care. That is what will happen if this government is re-elected.

There are some other serious problems associated with the bill that is before us tonight, in addition to the accommodation charge. I will turn to those briefly. Members on both sides would know that the residential aged care sector in this country is highly regulated to make sure that high quality care is provided and that nursing home and hostel beds go to those who need them most. That was the principle that was established under Labor and it is a principle that should remain under this government. But, under this bill, people seeking nursing home care must be classified as suitable for nursing home or hostel careâthat is okay. This will be done by aged care assessment teams, also a good initiative put in place by the previous Labor government. But of considerable concern and a matter which I would like the minister to follow up in his response is clause 57A-2(1)(a)(ii), which says:
if the approvalâ
for the aged care assessment teamâ
is not accompanied by any statement . . .
That is, a statement that a person be suitable for hostel or nursing home care, a person could still enter a nursing home or hostel if:
. . . the care recipient and the approved provider have agreed that an accommodation charge is to be payable.

I would appreciate it if the minister could assure the House that this does not mean that you do not need an assessment from an aged care assessment team; all you need, if you want a bed, is to agree to pay. If the minister could clarify the meaning of this subsection and why on earth it is even in there, I think it would be extremely helpful to all Australians in their concern to make sure that access to nursing home and hostel care will remain entirely on the basis of health need alone. It would be a sorry day, indeed, if we were to see a change occur in this country that enabled people to buy their way into nursing home care.

The second area I would appreciate further information about is in section 57A-6(1)(b) on page 16 of the bill. This sets out the maximum amount of accommodation charges. As I read the clause I have referred to, it does seem to be the case that the government wants to increase the accommodation charge way beyond the $4,380. Once again, I would ask the minister whether this is correct because it seems to enable the government, at some time in the future after the next election, by merely changing the user rights principlesâwhich, of course, do not have to come into the parliamentâto increase the accommodation charge.

I repeat the point because we have already seen, in a letter from the minister to the Prime Minister, that the government has already agreed on a cap of $5,500 but hoped to keep it a secret, as the letter said, to avoid raising community concerns. Community concerns will certainly be raised by this legislation if there is no limit in the act on what can be charged. The way the bill seems to be drafted at the moment is exactly that way. As I said at the outset, Labor will be opposing the introduction of this accommodation charge. I will be moving a number of amendments, when we get to the detailed stage of debate, to remove all reference to the charge from this bill.

There are a number of other specific areas I would like to raise and ask the minister to respond to. The first is the definition of hostel and nursing home care. The bill defines hostel care as meaning residential care for care recipients who do not have a continuing need for nursing care or who do have a need for nursing care in the case of nursing home residents. What I would like to know is: where is nursing care defined?

The second issue is in relation to what I understand is described by the minister as a drafting error in the original legislation. I find it inconceivable that the government managed to draft the original legislation last year in such a way that it was impossible to take sanctions for breach or revoke approval against a provider for breaches prior to 1 October 1997. This flaw is yet another example of the continuous bungling by this government of this aged care issue. Fancy taking away the capacity for the government to revoke the approval of or put sanctions on a provider that had done the wrong thing before October last year. It is a shameful state of affairs that we find ourselves in. I very much hope, in the interests of elderly people and their families and the certainty that they need about the future of their accommodation needs when they become very frail and sick, that we will get some answers to the problems that have been put to the government tonight.

As a result of this government's charges, many people are no longer seeking the nursing home care that they need. The responsibility for this care is falling back onto families and falling onto public hospitals, and it is these people who are feeling the blowtorch of the cuts this government made to aged care and the enormous amount of incompetence and bungling that has taken place after that change. It is a shameful way to treat one of the most vulnerable groups of people in this country and should be condemned. (Time expired)
