talk.start.para: âIt gives me great pleasure to speak to the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998. In doing so, particularly as I am following the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), I would like to return to the most important part of this bill: why is the government, in the first place, trying to change the way in which we finance residential aged care?

speech.para: Late in 1995, about six months after my preselection, which I found to be a character building experience, the Premier of Western Australia, Mr Richard Court, gave me a piece of advice which I have used to good effect and which I will never forget. He said to me, `Brendan, just remember that you are only there once, and the saddest thing that you will ever see in politics is someone who leaves it regretting that they did not say or do what they knew to be right when they had the opportunity to do it.' What this government, of which I am privileged and proud to be a member, is doing is something that is not necessarily popular, but it is right and it is in the interests of Australia much more than it is in the interests of any individual member of this government, or indeed the party political fortunes of the Liberal Party.

The Hawke-Keating government failed Australia in two principal ways, and both of those failures are addressed in no small way by this bill. It failed us, firstly, by allowing us to become a country in which we finance essential social infrastructure, of which aged care is one of the most important aspects, on debt and asset sales instead of on income. Secondly, it failed us by allowing us to become a country in which we expect that there will be an unsustainable capacity of government to deliver all of the things that we want and all of the things that we need. It allowed us in some ways to become a selfish country: a people far more concerned about our rights than our responsibilities and about the here and nowâwhat is going to happen todayârather than having any kind of meaningful respect for the past and certainly any meaningful planning for the future.

What the government is seeking to do in aged care addresses those two principal failures. This amendment bill will give effect to the intention of the government, because what the government is trying to do is to see that 20 or 30 years from now there is a place available in residential aged care and, more importantly, that it is a place in which we would be happy to have either of our parents or, indeed, ourselves live; in other words, it is a place of quality. The government is also seeking to see that this is financed on income, that it is not financed on a legacy of debt that we leave the next generation and that we have the courage, as the Australian Labor Party did in 1988 in introducing entry contributions to the hostel sector, and the foresight now in 1998 to introduce and implement measures that will see Australia and residential aged care well into the next century.

The context in which these reforms are being effected is this: about five per cent of us eventually will need some form of residential aged care; about 130,000 Australians currently live in residential aged care institutions; currently about 13 per cent of us are over the age of 65; and halfway through the next century a third of the people in this country will be over the age of 65. In fact, there are 2.2 million people currently over the age of 65 and, on present changing demographics, that will double over the next 30 years. About eight per cent of us over the age of 75 will suffer, in the absence of a cure, from dementia. Of the most rapidly growing age group in the communityâthe over-85sâ24 per cent currently suffer from dementia, and the next 40 years will see a 300 per cent increase in this age group alone. Last year Australia had 1,660 centenarians; by 2060 there will be 54,000.

If you go back to Professor Bob Officer's report to the National Commission of Audit, which he released in July 1996, and you turn to the chapter on health and then to the chapter on aged care, you will find a number of things. In 1993 the number of Australians between the ages of 15 and 64 was 5.3 to 1; in 40 years time it will be 2.6 to 1âit is called an aged dependency ratio. Over the next 40 years we are going to have to spend 10 per cent more of our gross domestic product, our nation's entire productivity, on the health and welfare costs of ageing, above and beyond real growth from where we are currently at, just to sustain the level of services that we are currently providing and which Australians have come to expect. If you further consider that last year there were around seven million Australians who worked and paid tax to support 6.2 millionâmost, through no fault of their own, relying on some form of social security benefitâyou realise that something has to change.

What the member for Jagajaga and others who perhaps are well intentioned on the other side of the House fail to appreciate is that you can cannot live in an economy which is growing at around three per cent and, on the one hand, deny transport, energy, taxation and regulatory reform and, on the other, turn around and say, `But, yes, we will have free education and higher education for everybody, we will have free aged care provided for everybody irrespective of their means, and we will have free health services provided to everybody irrespective of their background.' No matter how noble the intention, it is simply not a sustainable concept. At some stage the government, as the previous government did in 1988 in relation to hostels, has to take some difficult but responsible decisions.

We need also to consider that the debate of this bill occurs in the context of three major reviews initiated by the previous governmentâagain to its creditâwhich examined the state of Australia's nursing home sector, the most comprehensive of which was under taken by Professor Bob Gregory, who was then a member of the Reserve Bank board and professor of economics at the Australian National University. The second stage of that report was delivered in 1994.

Gregory found that in 1994 we had to spend $1,000 million to bring up the standard of Australian nursing homes to meet fire, design, health and outcomes standards. The Valuations Office, which was a significant part of that inquiry, found that, of 150 nursing homes, 75 per cent of them needed to be significantly repaired or completely rebuilt to meet design standards, 70 per cent failed to meet outcomes standards and 13 per cent did not meet fire standards, and that 39 per cent of residents in nursing homes lived in a room with at least three other people, 13 per cent lived in a room with at least five other people and 12 per cent lived in rooms that contained at least six beds. Gregory went on to say:

The lack of incentive to maintain good quality nursing home stock is a result of the funding system under which nursing homes receive a set amount for each resident based on frailty, which is the same regardless of the age or condition of the building.

To complete the scenario: whilst all of this was occurring, Labor was reducing the capital funding provided to nursing homes from $45 million in 1992-93 to $10.7 million in 1995-96. Keep in mind that when the member for Jagajaga was making her contribution to this debate she berated us for the fact that this government committed itself recently to an additional $20 million for capital funding. She criticised the government for that. That is twice what her government intended to spend for the entire sector in 1995-96.

At the same time, our government, the Howard government, is committing $40 million for nursing home capital in regional and disadvantaged areas, not to mention the money that will be raised after four years from the income stream of $130 million a year through accommodation contributionsâin other words, coming into the sector from those people who are its primary beneficiaries: those who are going into it. Australia needs to ensure that we live in a society in which everybody feels that they will be cared for and knows they will be cared for irrespec tive of their means or their background, but in return we are all expected to make some contribution to the society from which we derive some benefit.

Amongst the things said by the member for Jagajaga on the occasion of this bill being debated and indeed others is that the generation most immediately affected by this are people who have sacrificed for most of their lives, who have saved for most of their lives, and now they may be required to make some contribution to their residential aged care. This is a generation who grew up during the Depression. The first generation affected by this measure are people who went to war or sent their family members or those whom they loved to war. They are people whose sacrifices made this country what it is. They are people who did not buy something until they had saved for it.

What I say to that generation is thank you for leading us for the last century and what we are trying to do here is to not only ensure that we raise money that can be spent only on your care and only on your accommodation, if you are in the situation where you might be able to afford to pay it, but also change cultural expectations. We are trying to build the kind of future in which young people especially understand that they cannot spend all their money on a Bali holiday or a nice car, that they actually have to give some thought to who will be financing their higher education and their aged care and paying for their pension and all of the things that I think over the last 13 or 14 years many Australians have come to take for granted.

A couple of points that ought to be made about the accommodation charge are, firstly, it is a maximum of $4,380 a year, or $12 a day, for those who have assets in excess of $45,000 a year and for those with assets between $22,500 and $40,000 there is a sliding scale of between $6 and $12 a day. The legislation requires that that can be spent in only one of three ways: on building capital in which you will live or retiring debt that has been used to build that capital; on upgrading the capital, the accommodation, within which you live; or, in the absence of those two things, on the provision of care and services to you.

In terms of income tested daily fees, people seem to forget that amongst the things we are doing is trying to amalgamate the hostel and the nursing home sector. Forty per cent of people living in hostels today actually should be in a nursing home because they have levels of dependency which meet those requirements. Couples can face a dreadful situation, as I found when I was looking after people who were sick, where they, after being married for 50 years, go into a hostel but, when one of them subsequently has a stroke or is faced with some other disaster and is required to move to a nursing home, they are forcibly separated. Under the reforms the government is undertaking in amalgamating the two sectors, that will no longer be required.

In the hostel sector up until now hostel proprietors have been required to leave residents with around $57 a week. After the first $49 a week, which is the pension free area, they could take dollar for dollar whatever the resources and income hostel residents had. We are saying that people will be required to pay after the first $49 a week, which cannot be touched, 25c in the dollar to a maximum of $63.30 a day. In order to be paying $63.30 a day for your care, you would have to be earning $56,000 a year or, a married couple, $112,000 a year.

One of the other points that was raised by the member for Jagajaga, and which is raised repeatedly, is that this government has allegedly ripped $500 million out of aged care. What it actually has done is reduce the rate of growth in the forward estimates from expenditure in aged care. We increased by 6.7 per cent in the 1996-97 budget the amount of money we spent on residential aged care. In last year's budget we increased it by 4.2 per centâ2,200 new nursing home places this year and 2,800 new community aged care packages.

But what we have done is to ask Australians who could afford to do so to make a contribution to their care at a time when they most need it. In doing so, we will ensure that we have nursing home stock that is of quality, that it is sustainably financed and that there is a place available 20 or 30 years from now. In also doing so, it will ensure that the older generation of Australians will help lead Australia into the next century and change some of the cultural values and unrealistic and, dare I suggest, selfish expectations of younger generations, including my own.

talk.start.para: âThe Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998 , I have to say, is a testament to the very ad hoc approach to social policy which has characterised this government since its election. The government so far has presided over a series of complicated changes, none of which have been clearly explained or justified before the next ones are announced. All of them, as far as I can see, have been driven by a very narrow ideological focusâand we have heard some of that from the previous speaker, the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson)âwhich imposes increasing burdens on service users and their families while removing taxpayer funded supportâover $500 million worth. I think it is worth saying to the previous speaker that they are cuts, because the forward estimates are based on a careful assessment of the numbers who are likely to need it in the future times a cost escalation. So when you cut funds out of that it is a real cut, believe me.

speech.para: It is not surprising that the community, as a result of all this, is confused, very anxious and angry, not only about what is happening right now but also about what the government might do next. The Council of the Ageing's December newsletter was headlined `Aged care on shifting ground'. Ministers have often accused the opposition of scaremongering. The reality is that we did not need to do any more than draw attention to the policy's all too evident deficiencies. Anyone confronted with these policies is scared by its mean-mindedness, by its lack of respect for the aged, by its indifference to decent universal provision of affordable aged care and by what, I must say, is breathtaking double speak which has accompanied the government's defence of its cuts in public provision and its imposts on the frail, elderly and their familiesâthe people the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) called `the millionaires squatting in nursing home accommodation'. That attitude speaks volumes.

The executive director of the Council of the Ageing in Western Australia put in the December newsletter, `Are you confused over the recent debacle on aged care?' A rhetorical question to which they answer, `If so, you are not alone'. Indeed. There have been at least 14 separate changes to the operation of the Howard government's very destructive aged care residential policy. Even their own members clearly do not understand it and those who do often deliberately misrepresent it. For more than a year, for example, they denied over and over again that the policy would require many people to sell their family homes. We heard the former minister say it many times in this place. Yet, when announcing the changes to the entry charges, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) said that the family home is now safeâa tacit admission that it had been under threat, as we said.

Despite all the changes we have seen in the last two years, sadly the government still does not have it right. Changing the minister and making a few cosmetic changes to the charging arrangement do not remedy the basic flaws in the coalition's approach. Indeed, in some respects, it makes it a good deal worse.

I must say that I have had some cause for amusement in this respect. I remember well the former shadow minister, as he was then, the now Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge), making certain statements in the lead-up to the 1995 budget. There was a big budget leak, and there were a lot of supposed health care cuts, including aged care. It was the usual department of finance wish list. They fell for it in opposition and they fell for it in government. What was on that list? What was the shadow minister, now minister, saying at the time? He said in an interview he gave on 2GB to Les Thompson on 9 February:
I suspect they'll look for entry contributions or look for people who are in nursing homes to pay greater than they're paying at the moment.

He was accusing the former government of that. Yes, that was on the finance wish list, and I rejected it. The current minister said at the time that I would be rolled. He was the one who was rolled, comprehensively, in the last two budgets. He also said that there would be a means test for nursing homes, that there would be increases in pharmaceutical benefits costs for pensioners and cuts to the home and community care program. Sound familiar? These are all the things that happened under this government. He said on the same day in a different interview on Channel 10 TV news:
I really don't know how anyone could be stupid enough to propose some of these things.
Not only did the current government propose them but they enacted them. That is what this bill is all about. He went on to say on 6PR on the same day in 1995âhaving a field day that day:
If you are going to do itâ
when he was challenged about cutting spendingâ
don't do it in a way that slugs elderly and vulnerable people such as nursing home users or slugs pensioners in their access to pharmaceuticals.

Let us have no crocodile tears from members opposite. They warned us about it and then proceeded to do it. Let us look first at the accommodation chargeâsomething they said we were threatening to do but in fact had no intention of doing. It was, I might say, something that Professor Gregory explicitly rejected as a suitable option.

The Prime Minister has made much of his government's abandonment of the so-called accommodation bond, which would have required a massive up-front payment to enter a nursing homeâ$13,000âwhich, plus interest, could be retained by the nursing home over a five-year period. It would certainly have necessitated selling the family home, as the Prime Minister subsequently admitted.

Following the outcry from older Australians and their worried families, the government in this legislation is replacing the bond with a chargeâsemantics do not confuse anybodyâof $4,380 per year for up to five years, or, as we have heard, $12 a day for those with assets, including the family home, over $44,400, and a sliding scale for figures between $22,500 and $44,399. I think it is worth pointing out here that over 70 per cent of aged pensioners have only one assetâthe family homeâand it is bound to be worth more than $44,400. In other words, the total cost is higher than with the accommodation bond, especially since the rent or proceeds of the sale will affect tax paid.

The arrangements still necessitate selling the family home or, at best, renting it or taking out a mortgage, something these people certainly have not looked to in their later years. It is perfectly possible, as we have heard from our shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), that this charge may increase. It has been toyed with by the current government. The original level was set higher. Some of the nursing home proprietors who are close to the governmentâthe actual millionaires rather than the millionaire squatters talked about by the Deputy Prime Ministerâare still demanding more. They say that the new arrangements and the cuts to capital funding will mean that they do not have enough money for upgrades and rebuilding.

Let us look at the extra daily charge. From 1 March all new residents of aged care facilities also have their income tested to assess their liability for extra daily fees, something the current minister said we would do, and we did not. He fell for the three-card trick from the finance department. This is a very old set of proposals and a very bad one. They will have to pay an extra 25c in the dollar for each dollar of private income over $50 a week. I am sure I heard the minister responsible and the Prime Minister say that these people are well off. You have got to be kidding! They have to pay an extra fee of up to $258.30 per week. But the important thing here is that this does not buy any extra services. The government claws back the same amount in reduced payments to the facilities, not one extra service.

The major churches made a combined call to the government on 27 February for urgent aged care changes. It shows that the major not-for-profit providers are far from happy. They understand what is happening. They are unhappy about both the capital funding and the extra daily charges. They point out, quite accurately, something that the minister has repeatedly denied in this House. I quote from their press release:
In actual fact, the extra daily fees do not contribute any extra money to the upkeep of the homes, the care of the residents or the future development of the services.

That needs to be underlinedânot one extra dollar. They also describe the capital arrangements as totally unsatisfactory, leaving, as they put it, the residential sector `stranded'. In this press release they called on the government, which is clearly ignoring them, since this bill will go through unamended apparently, to `ease the burden on our most vulnerable citizens'.

I want to take a moment to have a look at who these people are. Who are these residents of our nursing homes and hostels, looking specifically at nursing homes? The government seems to have forgotten just who these people are. They are not millionaire squatters. As the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare's report on nursing homes dated June 1996 shows, 71 per cent of these residents are women, 65 per cent are over 80 and 55 per cent were on a pension of some kind. Millionaires? At least 46 per cent were admitted straight from hospital. They are supposed to put their finances in order in that condition?

The report showed that a significant proportion of these residents are widowed, they have no-one immediately to look to and over 50 per cent were assessed as requiring more than 23.5 hours of care a week, the highest level. They need a lot of health careâthis is not about accommodationâwith a further 37 per cent needing between 19.5 and 23.5 hours of care. That is very intensive medical care. Over 30 per cent of the residents are there for less than a year and the majority of `separations'â85 per centâare the result of death. These are amongst the poorest and frailest members of our community, yet they are the ones that the Deputy Prime Minister calls millionaire squatters. Most of them clearly are at the end of their lives and they require a caring and peaceful environment, not anxiety and not change.

We have heard that these residents have contributed through war service, through paying taxes, raising children and through community service to our country's wellbeing. And this is the thanks they get from this government, a government who promised them much. They already make a contribution through their daily fees. They are not getting something for nothing. Why make them pay more at a time when the last thing they need is to consider complicated financial arrangements which could leave them with an extra tax burden as well? There have been adverse effects of these changes already. I have seen the effects of the changes in my own electorate and throughout my state of Western Australia. But I have not heard anything from the Western Australian members either here or in the Senate about those effects, yet they are very visible.

One of the things that is happening right now is that occupancy rates in nursing homes are already falling, an extraordinary thing when you look at the pent-up demand. Even the newest and most comfortable facilities, including new ones in my electorate, are reporting unprecedented vacancies. Families are clearly using ad hoc arrangements and, as a result, there is even greater pressure on the already stretched home and community care programs and of course on the families themselves. There is the extra cost and the uncertainty. They are not even going into the nursing homes where they need the care. In many cases they have been assessed as needing the care. In the nursing homes themselves, to save costs, the facilities are already employing fewer and less qualified staff. Talk to anyone in the industryâthey are having to do it.

In my own state the local branch of the Department of Health and Family Services are clearly stretched to the limit. I know some of the people there. I have a great deal of respect for them. They are trying to respond to queries from worried proprietors, operators and families. They are at the limit. I have been told from very reliable sources within the industry that the department have asked the nursing homes to stop ringing them and to put all their requests for information and clarification of the government's muddle in writingâno more phone calls from the sector.

The new resident classification scale has already had a disastrous effect on hostels, particularly those catering for people from a non-English speaking background in my electorate. In that scale, cultural and language needs have been downgraded.

In my electorate the Italian village is encountering grave financial problems and this has prompted the families and supporters of the facility, not usually given to political action, to petition the minister to provide additional funds. I read from their letter which, after describing the facility, says amongst other things:
You are no doubt aware of the impact to which the new classification scale has had on the rating given to communication. This is of grave concern to our Hostel.
Most of these people's first language is not English. The letter goes on:
The financial impact is very serious, with the potential shortfall in cashflow having to be recovered from the residents, who are all on age pensions, and or their immediate families.
It goes on to say:

We implore you to reconsider the proposed changes, consider the mental and emotional anguish imposed on the aged (all of whom have paid their dues) and consider the rights of an individual and the collective role they play in electing the next Government.

In response, I did get the department to go out and have a look at what was going on there, and they are right. They are going to lose fundingâalthough the minister reassures them in a bland letter:
. . . the facility will have a net increase in funding under the new RCS compared with the previous classification instrument.

He must think they are idiots! They have done their sums and they are losing money. We have also received many calls from worried older men and women and their families who cannot understand why the government has been attacking them. `Why us?' they say, `What have we done?' They cannot understand why the government has been attacking them on so many fronts: nursing home and hostel charges; increases in the prices of their medicines; cuts to public hospital funding and increased waiting lists; abolition of the Commonwealth's contribution to dental care; and, of course, the threat of a GST. Is it any wonder that the older members of our communityâmy community, every community in Australiaâfeel betrayed and angry with this shambles of a government? It is alarming that in his second reading speech the minister says proudly of these measures that they `promote our vision of a secure future for older Australians'. It looks to me like a glimpse into Dante's Inferno. This vision is why these same older Australians keep asking in fear, `What will they do next?' What, indeed?

talk.start.para: âI was pleased to see the rearrangement of the speakers list here tonight because it gave the previous health minister an opportunity to speak before I did. Listening to her has been very interesting indeed because I find some of her remarks very fascinating. In referring to the government and this side of the House, she refers to `they': `they' cut taxpayer capital funded support. The government that cut the taxpayer funded capital support to the aged care sector was the previous government, of which the previous speaker, the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence), was the minister for health. She was definitely and inexplicably party to the cutting of that capital funding. If she and her predecessors in that role had not been party to it, why was the nursing home sector of this nation in such a deplorable state when we came to government? The evidence is there for us all to see.

speech.para: She talks about $500 million in forward estimates. The speaker before me was not only the health minister but also previously Premier of Western Australia, therefore a person who understands forward estimates more than anybody else in this place. Forward estimates are exactly thatâforward estimates. They are not a budget. The budget comes after the estimates.

She referred to confusion. I know that we all know where the confusion has come from. The confusion has come from the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) who, in the last 18 months of this parliament, has confused the elderly people of Australia so much that they are terrified, and my sympathy goes out to them. I spend much of my time speaking to them and assuring them and I find that, once I have given them the information on what the government is doing, I get understanding. But when you get what is supposed to be compassion from the other side being nothing more than confusion and scare tactics, how do you expect an elderly person to react? It is a typical political ploy.

I now address some of the points I would like to raise in this debate which I believe are important for the people of Australia to understand. Over the last few months as I have met with nursing home proprietors, managers, staff and also, might I say, with the Queensland nursing union, I have been amazed at the conditions under which they have had to work for the past 13 years. On the surface, many nursing homes and hostels appear to be running smoothly, but the reality is that they have been fighting a losing battle to maintain even moderately acceptable standards. These do not generate overnight; they are a symptom of a long, sore problem that has been going on for years.

That this government tackled the problems facing our nursing homes is not surprising; reform has always been carried out by the Liberal and National parties. But what is more surprising is that the men and women of the previous government are still tenaciously fighting to retain a flawed, and what was a failing, system. If you adopt the logic that those who can make a contribution towards their aged care do so, our policy, I believe, makes a great deal of sense. Until the Howard government came under attack from the Labor Party for this policy, I do not believe too many people, including the department of family services, realised just how deep and widespread were the problems in the nursing home and aged care sector.

We literally exposed what the Labor Party had kept hidden: the state of our aged care facilitiesâa situation that I consider a national disgrace. The crux of the entire issueâour rapidly increasing aged populationâhad been ignored. For the first time in our history we have a declining birth rate and a rapidly increasing life expectancy. Yet we are a nation of people with a high expectation of government sponsored retirement income. This problem has been niggling away at governments for decades.

The member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) recently did some serious research and revealed that there were attempts to start up a retirement income schemeâan aged pension schemeâthat involved compulsory participation as far back as 1930. But Australians could not be persuaded to think long term. As a result it was not until the early 1970s, when government initiated an inquiry into retirement income, that compulsory superannuation was introducedâa measure that I wholeheartedly support. But this first foray into encouraging the population to put aside retirement funds from the day they start earning an income came too late to help all those aging and unwell people who need nursing home care now and in the immediate future.

The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) let this country down by reducing the government's contribution to aged care to such an extent that it takes an annual contribution of $3 billion dollars to maintain what I call a basic adequate standard of care. Today there are only 137,000 Australians in nursing homes or hostels. Of these, 65 per cent are on full government support. They are full pensioners. They do not and will not have to contribute to their care over and above their existing pension contribution. That has operated in this sector for years. This government acknowledges there will always be members of the community who cannot, through no fault of their own, provide for their retirement care. There are others who, due to severe ill health, are simply not capable of managing their lives.

This is acknowledged in this bill, and one of the many amendments addressing this situation extends the time period to reach a payment agreement for those who have a mental impairment and who, obviously, have the ability to make a contribution. It is recognised that these and some other people need the support and advice of a financial administrator.

The amendments in this bill also clarify provisions which limit the kinds of fees which can be charged to residents. This amendment makes it clear that waiting lists and administration fees cannot be chargedâpart of the scare tactics campaign of the opposition. It also introduces provisions that will enable the Commonwealth to take action against any provider who has been convicted of serious crimes such as abuse of residents or fraud.
I believe it is totally irresponsible for the opposition to continue to rant and rave about the so-called injustice of asking those who can afford to make a contribution towards their care to do so.

This government, unlike the previous government, is educating all Australians in the need to consider preparing themselves for their retirementâsomething that this country should have faced a long time ago. I do not believe that it is fair to expect young Australians to put aside funds for their own retirement while at the same time paying to support those who did not.

The Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) and his staff have worked diligently to improve the process of aged care reform that has been introduced by this government. If the opposition was serious in its claims that it cares for the aged, constructive criticism would have been a help to everyone in this nation, particularly the aged. But we all know that this was not the case. The opposition has persisted with a scare campaign of such magnitude that elderly people have been quite terrified when they hear Labor's great untruth that they are going to be left homeless.

This government has listened to the people and has implemented changes to this bill to ensure their fears are allayed. The bill reduces from five to two years the period that a co-resident carer must have lived in the family home for it to be excluded from consideration for concessional resident status. This government is aggressive and innovative when it comes to reform; it has had to be with an aged care industry in crisis and a government debt that we inherited of $10.5 billionâbequeathed to the nation by the former Fi nance Minister, now Leader of the Opposition.

It would have been easy but crass to have taken television cameras through substandard nursing homes, showing the nation the appalling conditions in which some of our aged lived, which was a legacy of 13 years of the previous government. While it would have made a dramatic and fast television moment, it would have also reflected badly on all those hardworking nurses, providers and staff who have provided excellent care for their patients. That this government responded quickly to the need of our aged community to improve the standard of nursing homes has in many cases been lost in the scare campaign by the Labor Party. The sad truth is that many nursing homes are below standard. Many are borderline, which means that in another few years they will be substandard.

The industry has been crying out for reform, and this government was swift to respond by introducing accommodation charges for those who can afford to pay them. The Labor Party was equally swift in decrying the reforms and, thanks to their scare campaign, the initial goalâto improve the lives of our nursing home residentsâwas set back and delayed. These reforms must happen for the future of all our citizens, and the Aged Care Amendment Bill before us today goes towards ensuring this government's ultimate goalâthat is, good quality nursing home care for the aged members of our community who require nursing home care.

The amendments in this bill make it clear that every avenue possible has been introduced to ensure no person is unfairly disadvantaged. I point to the amendment which deals with the fees that providers are able to charge residents. Provisions have been added that will prohibit the charging of any extra fees that could result in significant extra costs for residents beyond those already allowed by the act. It should be realised that those people who will be asked to pay the maximum daily fee must have assets which produce an income of $56,000 a year.

It is also realised by this government that there will be some people whose only asset is their home. I could not do better than to cite my own family. While my father chose to sell our family home to contribute to his care, not everyone wishes to do so; and they do not have to. One major element of this bill is to exclude rental income and the value of the home from the pension income and assets test where a person is renting out their house to pay the accommodation charge. In this way they keep their asset and still contribute towards their nursing home care.

The nursing home debate, or, should I say, the nursing home reform, tackles an issue which is not palatable to a small section of the Australian community: those who believe that the stateâthat is, the taxpayerâshould support them from cradle to grave. As far as the Labor Party is concerned, it has been purely political chicanery. I notice that the member for Jagajaga, in attacking this reform, never mentions just how the opposition propose to resolve the matter of supporting our aged and infirm, except, of course, by increasing taxation: Labor's answer to every problem. I believe it is timely to ask this question: when the member for Jagajaga was the minister's chief adviser, why did she allow the standard of nursing homes to deteriorate to such an alarming degree? The previous government allowed our 3,000 aged care facilities to run down to the point where more than 250 simply do not meet state and federal basic health standards. Others are only just skirting the safety line and without massive capital funding will continue to deteriorate.

I was amazed to hear a talkback radio listener say that this situation did not matter. This nameless person told the radio audience that for many people even a substandard nursing home was an improvement on where they had been living before. He said that at least they received three meals a day and, even if they shared a room, they had a bed. I do not believe substandard aged care should be the goal of the nation. The bottom line is: just what has the opposition offered? Absolutely nothingâexcept, of course, disinformation to frighten our aged community and their families. And all for nothing more than political gain. I support this bill and this government's aged care reform.

talk.start.para: âAt the very start let us get it very clear. I came into this parliament in March 1983, and we were advised within weeks that the previous Treasurer had been advised prior to the election of a deficit in prospect of, in today's equivalent, $25 billion. He did not deny that. In other words, the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) had been told by Mr Stone from Treasury before the election in 1983 of the deficit in prospect on his budget of August 1982. Quite frankly, I get fed up with the kind of hypocrisy and cant coming from the government about the supposed deficit, which was not authenticated, which was not documented. Originally it was $6 billion, then $7 billion and $8 billion. Every month the number kept changing. Quite frankly, I find it just a little bit tiresome.

speech.para: Despite that deficit, despite the double digit unemployment, despite the double digit inflation, despite the fact that in 1982, with John Howard as Treasurer, the manufacturing work force declined by eight per cent in one year aloneâdespite all thatâwe managed to lift pensions, we managed to extend benefits, and we managed to introduce hostels, which were barely in existence at the time. We managed to extend support for people who needed it. We could have done what those opposite have done, and are still doing, which is rip into the system, blame the victimsâwhether they be Asians, blacks, pensioners or people in nursing homesâblame somebody else, and become the pawns of Treasury and Finance.

So-called fiscal responsibility has been social irresponsibility. The debt that you are building up in this government is not about money; it is about social capital. It is a social debt. If you keep up this kind of line, you will pass on to generations ahead a burden they will not cope with. I suggest to anybody who is observing this debate on the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998 that they go back and read the speeches of the same people on this original legislationâhear them justify and defend the ripping away of half a billion dollars from the aged care sector, because they did not mention that.

Tonight we have had the previous speaker, the member for Griffith (Mr McDougall), talking about the condition of nursing homes. You would think that this was about benefiting nursing homes. The fact is that this legislation is financial. It has nothing to do with nursing homes; it is about money. It is about finding a way to make up for the half a billion dollars the government has cut out of the budget for residential aged care. That is what it was about the first time around. That is what it is about right now. It did not work then, and it does not work now.

But, in the meantime, what are you doing? You are blaming the victim. You are shooting the messenger. On the one hand, the government says, `You ran a scare campaign.' Then we hear tonight, from speaker after speaker, how the government listens to the people. If it was only a scare campaign, why would you have listened? Let me tell you why you listened: it is because you have been deceitful all the way through. You have tried to pretend that what you are trying to do is improve nursing homes, when we know that is not the case.

Two of these amendments go to matters where I had constituent submissions which I wrote to ministers about. The first was the five-year cohabitation issue. A constituent of mine had been living with her father for two years. She had left her job and left Sydney to come back home to care for her father. She was a woman in her 50s, so the prospects of finding work again were remote. When he had moved to a nursing home, as he was required to do because she could no longer care for him, not only did she have the burden of the guilt from not being able to care for her father any longer but also, as the sole beneficiary, she was required by your legislation, which we are now amending, to sell the family house to pay the up-front fees. You brought it back to two years because of that particular case. Week after week, the minister in this place insisted we were making that up, yet the correspondence was in her office all the time.

The second case involved the retrospective application of the $10,000 per year gifting provisions, which went back five years. I had a case of that as well. The family was bereft. The mother was going to be devastated by those provisions. Week after week, the government denied, procrastinated, stonewalled, accused us of scaremongering, said it did not exist, did not answer the correspondence for ages, and eventually capitulated. If I had not done that, could I have been said to have been representing my constituents? Of course I couldn't. Yet week after week I have heardâand I am hearing it again tonightâthat we were scaremongering. The hypocrisy in this debate is breathtaking.

Let us get the figures right again. The 1996 budget took out of the residential aged care system half a billion dollars over four yearsâ$130 million a year. The legislation for up-front fees was brought into this place and went through the parliament to recover that moneyânot to give extra money to aged care; simply to recover that which had been taken out. Your so-called deficit policy was off the backs of the families of people who needed residential aged care, nursing home care. That is where it came fromâhalf a billion dollars of it.

In the same way that you attacked the students, in the same way that you attacked the unemployed, in the same way you attacked a whole range of other peopleâpeople who wanted to sponsor a spouse, a brother, a sister, a niece, a nephewâyou attacked this sector. At first, the nursing home sector thought you meant what you said. They said, `This is terrific. Up-front fees will be great. It will be very helpful.' They did not understand what you were really doing. When they did and they made that clear, the government then started to change its tune.

There are a couple of things that need to be understood as well. There is one other aspect of what the government has done which is not in the legislation; it is about breach of contract. I want to quote yet again an example I have quoted in this place more than once to date because it is important that those opposite and the community at large understand the depths to which this government has sunkâand I say `depths' with some thoughtfulness. Maroba nursing home in Edith Street, Waratah, is a nursing home and hostel. A couple of years ago, they received a grant for $400,000 to upgrade and to extend. The grant was to be paid over 10 years at $40,000 per year. Altogether, they spent $1 million on their facility. That money was spent before this government came to power.

From recollection, when the announcement came out in the 1996 budget, they had received only two payments of that $40,000 a year. In other words, they were still owed $320,000. They were advised by letter, from recollection, in late 1996 that they had a choice: they could take up-front fees, or they could take their grantsâbut they could not have both. This was from a government that is telling us it is about getting extra spending for nursing homes to repair damage, to upgrade facilities.

This group had spent $1 million already; it had counted on the $400,000 from the Commonwealth to help pay for that. Of course, up-front fees were about the future, about expansion and improvementânot about paying last year's bills, which is what we are talking about. The contract they entered into was with the Australian government, as far as they were concerned. It was not with the Labor Party or some other party, but with the government. The composition of the government may change but, as far as I am concerned, its contracts do not change. That decision by the minister to revoke that contract, to my mind, is one of the most blatant and disgraceful breaches of faith one can imagine.

That organisationâwhich is run by a church group, incidentallyânow has to go out and try to raise the money. This is $320,000 that organisation has been dudded on. This is not some concoction; this is a sheer breach of contract. Mr Deputy Speaker, you may have noticed that some organisations are looking at taking legal action. I hope they do. I hope that we, in this chamber and in the other place, will move amendments to say to the government, `You've got to keep your contracts. You can't break a contract that was entered into in good faith; you've got to keep it.'

Let the government vote in favour of breaching its own contracts as a government. That is what it has done. It is what it is doing right now. And, at the same time, we get this cant from those opposite about how this is about lifting standards. It is about ripping $Â½ billion out of somebody else's pocketsâand what for? To create a social debt.

Money is always payable. Social debts, once incurred, cannot be recovered. They live on in people's psyche and in people's spirit, in their bodies and collective memories, for years and even decades to comeâthe hurt we do each other now, with this kind of social engineering. And that is what it is: it is social engineering of the worst kind because it is deceitful, dishonest and hypocritical. Social debts that we incur cannot be repaid.

We will pass on to our children and our children's children an enormous number of assets. They will inherit roads, railway lines, ports, buildingsâa whole range of things. But they will also inherit an amount of debt. Let me tell you: in my period in government, asset building vastly exceeded debt buildingâvastly exceeded it. We built a lot more assets in our society. For starters, just look at the national highway. Look at its current replacement cost compared with what it was when Labor was in government; look at what it would cost to put it in now.

The debts that we are passing on to our children, our grandchildren and future generations are accompanied by assets. As I have said, I have no embarrassment or shameâsimply prideâthat we improved the asset value much more than the debt value of what we are passing on. But what I cannot explain, what I cannot justify, is the pain we are passing on.

If we had not brought to the attention of the House and the government the kinds of problems that the legislation imposed, the woman of whom I spoke earlier would have been devastated and destroyed. I can tell you: the impact on that woman of what the government was doing was just unbelievable; she could not believe that any government would do that to her. Then there was the effect on the family of that mother's giftingâher giving her cash reserves to her grandchildren to help put deposits on houses; the govern ment was going to act as though she still had those cash reserves.

This woman does not get a pension. She is a full fee payer. She has no benefit at all. She was not performing any clever family trust trickâand that is what I find so appalling. Here we have good honest citizens, with, in so many cases, a house being all they have. I wonder who owns the houses of all those members in the government with family trusts; does the family trust own the house and, therefore, it is not affected? I am sure it probably does.

The way in which we see the government functioning, its members defending the use of artificial devices to protect assets for their children, and boasting about itâand then for us to see that government ripping into the assets of people who did not create that kind of artificiality is breathtaking in its hypocrisy. I suggest that people who speak in this debate go back and look at the speeches on the previous legislation to see how much has changed. Who and what are government members defending? They are defending the decision of Finance and Treasury to cut $Â½ billion. So no amount of talk about standards and all the rest will make up for that. It is about time that a few of them got a bit honest about it and actually came up-front and explained what they are doing.

The second fundamentally important thing that is going on in this debate is to do with the introduction by the government of the accreditation and assessment process that has taken place. I am sure that this has been mentioned in this place before: there has been correspondence from the nurses association, particularly up in the Hunter, regarding the way in which a single assessment instrument is being developed for nursing homes and hostels.

This is a complex issue, but it is fiendishly clever what the government is doing: the government is completely rewriting the actual schedules of assessment in a very clever way. The effect of it is to give a greater amount of money to people who are much more frail, particularly people suffering from Alzheimer's. That is understandable; we are aware that we have a problem there. But, rather than doing it by increasing expenditure, the government is shifting funds from the other recipients.

The compression and shifting of scales that is being undertaken in the resident classification scale or in the changes to it is going to mean two thingsâand, quite frankly, one cannot be sure what it will mean eventually because it is still such an experimental exercise. There are no pilots going on. This has not been tested in a pilot and proven through. This has been brought in with a bang. With this government, once again, we have the big bang theory. We are seeing it in the employment market. We used to be accused of being social engineers. These people are social engineers par excellence everywhereânot only with our aged, but with our frail and with our families.

I referred to a letter from the Hunter region aged care facility directors of nursing associations. Firstly, these people are all professional nurses and, secondly, are involved in directing aged care facilities. They have written a letter of some length and detail expressing an absolute abhorrence at what is happening. They are concerned about a significant reduction in direct care subsidies associated with the instrument. The compression of scales means that the payments per person of the different scales will be shifted. In regard to that one nursing home I mentioned earlier, if that scale were applied now to the current residents, they would be $100,000 a year worse offâbang, instantly. There goes $100,000 on their bottom line. This is a church group. They have already lost $320,000 in grant money. They are having trouble with the up-front fees question. They share the pain of the half a billion dollar cuts anyhow. With this instrument coming in, there is a $100,000 effect on current residents. If they were to have those residents come in now on this current scale, that is what the effect would be.

Mr Deputy Speaker Quick, you were not in the chair when the previous speaker, the honourable member for Griffith (Mr McDougall), made a point which I think is worth pointing out. He made the point that in the aged care facilities around Australia 65 per cent of people are on the full pension. I think when he made that point he thought he was saying something fairly important. Sixty-five per cent of people in nursing homes and hostels are on full benefits. In other words, their income falls below the asset and income test levels. What he did not say was that the government legislation provides for nursing homes to keep only 27 per cent of the beds for people who cannot afford these feesâ27 per cent, less than half. On the one hand, he tells us 65 per cent are currently in there. What the government is saying is that in the future it will be 27 per cent.

What is clear in all of this is that the government do not understand how nursing homes and hostels work. They do not understand the cash flow and the capital outlays. They never have and they still do not. What the nursing homes will have to do is maximise their income by seeking and accepting people who can pay the highest possible fees. It is the only answer they have. They are forced to take 27 per cent of people who have no money. Therefore, they are forced to maximise the others. What will happen will be a very simple selection process. Those who can pay the most will get in the fastest. Those who cannot will not. It will be as simple as that. Between 27 per cent and 65 per cent, that 38 per cent gap, what do they do? They squat. We heard about them squattingâsquatting in hospitals, squatting anywhere. There will be nowhere to go. Yet we hear that this is about improving standards. It is a disgrace. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI am sorry that I have such a limited time to talk because I would like to spend most of the time showing the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris) exactly where he is wrong in the things that he said. The last thing he was speaking about was the 27 per cent concessional patients and the gap of 38 per cent. I would like to point out to him that 27 per cent is the minimum, not a maximum. Anyone can take as many concessional patients as they like. The government has provided for a higher government subsidy for concessional patients in lieu of income that has been derived from the accommodation charge. Let us get that bit right first.

speech.para: I turn to the second bit. Let us get the bit about cohabitation right. You were saying that because a lady in Newcastle had not lived with her father for five years she had problems because she had to sell her home. I would like to point out that under Labor there was no protection whatsoever for the family home. It was counted in the assets test under the hostel entry contribution, and there was no protection and there was no exemption. You have no right to stand up and accuse us of taking the family home. There was no protection there whatsoever for it.

I have good news for the elderly in Australia. This government has introduced a plan that will allow nursing home residents the option of renting their home and having that rental income exempt from the pension income test and from the calculation of daily fees. This policy has direct benefits to pensioners. It allows the pensioner to keep the family home, it gives the pensioner peace of mind knowing that some day they may be able to return to their home, it provides them with cash flow that does not affect their pension, and no-one will have to sell their family home to enter a nursing home. Even a staunch critic of the government, Francis Sullivan, from the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, agrees that no-one will have to sell their home to enter a nursing home. On 4 February 1998 he said on the World Today radio program:
The change in government policy means that people are not going to have to be selling their homes to go into a nursing home.

What about the tax on rental, I hear the critics ask. Yes, pensioners will pay tax on their rental income. However, as taxpayers they become eligible for a tax rebate of 20c in the dollar on their health care costs that exceed $1,250 a year. I also hear critics say, `But you will never reach $1,250 a year.' Yes, they will because as a result of a lot of hard work the tax man has been convinced that daily care fees for nursing homes should be considered as legitimate health care costs and are therefore tax deductible. This is great news for the elderly in my electorate of Lilley and for the rest of Australia.

Over the course of a year a resident's daily fees are approximately $7,700. Factor in the 20 per cent tax medical rebate, and a $1,290 deduction will be returned to the nursing home resident at the end of the financial year. It must be remembered that this $1,290 is just a base figure and does not take into account any other related health costs such as medicines or visits to the doctor.

I think everyone in the House would agree that a minimum tax rebate of $1,290, as well as a steady rental income, will go a long way to contributing towards a pensioner's accommodation charge of $4,380. This deduction under the medical expenses rebate is a significant relief for pensioners and their families. Allowing people to rent their homes without it affecting their pension entitlement is a good move on behalf of the government. It adds flexibility to the system and gives residents and their families a choice.

The good news does not stop there. I am in the process of lobbying the tax department to make a ruling on whether the annual accommodation charge of $4,380 can also be considered tax deductible. I am hopeful of a positive outcome and will keep the House informed. Part pensioners and self-funded retirees will also be able to claim this rebate, which effectively means that, if they rent their homes to contribute to their nursing home care, they will be paying minimal or no tax.

National Seniors Association Chief Executive, David Deans, in his press release on 11 March 1998, said that this rebate would soften the impact of nursing home charges and provide significant relief for self-funded retirees. Mr Deans used an example of self-funded retirees paying top-rate daily fees. The rebate would be $4,300 a year, which would almost cover the yearly accommodation charge in full. I urge honourable members to make sure this information is circulated to the seniors within their electorate.

This legislation puts in place the government's vision for our aged care system. It is a vision that includes a practical response to address Labor's legacy of inefficient and poorly maintained buildings, inadequate funding for dementia care, over-regulation, inflexibility, and the focus on paper work over the quality of care. The government's policy of creating a balance between public and private contribution will see over $850 million invested in the capital stock of nursing homes over the next four yearsâthat is, $850 million without having to ask the taxpayers to pay more than the $30,000 per resident they are already paying.

The result from the national certification audit of nursing homes and hostels has shown that a disturbing number of nursing homes do not meet basic standards. This is a legacy of the 13 years of Labor neglect. This is the problem that Professor Gregory told the now Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) about in 1994. This is the problem that Labor not only ignored but exacerbated by cutting nursing home capital funding.

Labor chose to ignore the findings of the 1994 Gregory report, which they commissioned, and, although these findings have been mentioned many times in this place, it bears repeating. The findings graphically sum up the crisis in nursing home care: 11 per cent of nursing homes did not meet fire standards; 15 per cent did not meet health regulations; 40 per cent of residents shared rooms with four or more beds; and 65 per cent of nursing homes did not meet required building codes.

Unfortunately, the system under Labor failed to stamp out poor conditions. The coalition will be working in partnership with industry and consumers to ensure that older people get the care and conditions they deserve. We are not blaming victims, as the member for Newcastle said; we are blaming Labor.

This bill also introduces strong protection for consumers and creates incentives for providers to invest in maintenance and improve building stock. It also ensures that older Australians have equitable access to aged care services that provide high quality standards of care and accommodation. No longer will they have to put up with substandard accommodation. Only good quality facilities will be able to charge an accommodation charge. If residents are required to pay an accommodation charge, every cent will be spent on improving the quality of nursing homes. None of it goes to the government.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak in support of the Aged Care Amendment Bill 1998 . The past 18 months have seen sweeping changes to the aged care system which will help us to provide for the elderly in the way that we should into the new century when older Australians will make up a substantially greater proportion of the population. We have many aged care facilities that are built to standards that are no longer acceptable in the broader community. As the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith) said in October last year:

speech.para: This Government believes that older Australians deserve better than they're getting now . . . we have a rapidly ageing population which deserves to live in comfort, privacy and with dignity.

One of the most contentious and difficult aspects of the structural reforms to aged care policy is the identification of an appropriate balance between the tax payerâor public funding of aged care servicesâand the financial contribution that some older people can make themselves. The changes proposed in the Aged Care Amendment Bill, especially the introduction of an accommodation charge for people requiring nursing home level care, strikes, we believe, an acceptable balance and positions the sector so that improvements can be made where necessary to both the standards of accommodation and the quality of care that our elderly people receive in residential aged care services.

This amendment bill introduces an accommodation charge for residents who require nursing home care. After a long period of consultation with those families which have elderly parents, the industry itself and representatives of the industry we saw the parties come together. It was clear that there were very special circumstances which needed to be taken into account in relation to nursing home level residents. This accommodation charge will mean that aged care facilities receive a substantial capital injection and it should alleviate the fears of older peopleâfears that were shamelessly promulgated by the opposition; fears that we saw right out in our remote regional areas. Older people were told day after day in the media that they were going to be forced to sell their homes. Older people who had already decided to sell their homesâwho did not need their homes; their sons and daughters had shifted awayâsuddenly felt guilty when they read day after day that it was something of a crime or a personal family disappointment to continue to contemplate selling their family home, even though they had no need of that property themselves. It was a very sad period when we saw, as a result of party politics, those most vulnerable in our community being attacked.

An accommodation charge is simply a contribution calculated on a daily basis towards the cost of a person's accommoda tion. The accommodation charge is then used by aged care providers to upgrade and maintain their facilities where that is necessary. Sadly, after decades of inappropriate and inadequate policy in relation to aged care facilities, in particular in relation to nursing homes, we find that many of those nursing homes do need an extra injection of capital funding. The accommodation charge is capped at $12 per day or $6 for assisted residents, that is, those residents with assets between $22,500 and $36,000. Concessional residents, those with assets of less than $22,500, or residents who meet the other hardship criteria will not pay an accommodation charge. About 27 per cent of residents needing nursing home level care will not have to pay an accommodation charge and will be considered concessional residents. So our policies will make sure that in Australia in the future elderly people can expect to enjoy equality of serviceânot differences according to the rich or the poor.

Aged care providers will receive a subsidy of up to $12 per day for concessional residents and $6 per day for assisted residents in their facilities. The maximum daily subsidy is payable when a facility has more than 40 per cent of assisted or concessional residents. Providers are therefore receiving an incentive to accommodate residents who do not have the income or assets to pay an accommodation charge, and all age care facilities will need to maintain a certain percentage of concessional residents. I cannot imagine anything fairer than that. The charge is payable for a maximum of five years.

Residents will also have a choice as to how they pay the charge. They may choose to defer the payment and to pay it from their estate, or they may choose a home equity loan. And that is nothing to do with death duties, as the previous speaker, the honourable member for Barton (Mr McClelland), suggested. That is another aspect of their scare campaign and a shameless way to try to invoke fear in the minds of the most vulnerable.

No-one who requires nursing home level care will have to sell their home to access this care. No-one who has been dependent on social security or other pension benefits should have any fear in Australia in the future about accessing care that will be of the highest order possible.

Other major provisions in this bill include that, where a carer has been living in the prospective resident's home for two years, the house will not be included as part of the assets test when assessing whether a nursing home level resident will have to pay an accommodation charge. Under the current act, the carer has to be living in the home for five years. These changes clearly reflect this government's commitment to carers and the vital role that they do fulfil. A prospective resident's home is also excluded if a partner or dependent child is living there. I suggest that the previous speaker go and do his homework before he makes other suggestions in this place.

The aged care amendments affirm and strengthen the consumer protection provisions in the Aged Care Act. In particular, the amendments introduce mechanisms to ensure that only providers who meet strict requirements and adhere to stringent guidelines are permitted to operate aged care facilities. We understand very well the duty of care that we have as an Australian society. The health and wellbeing of our parents, grandparents and other loved ones are too important for us to settle for anything less.

The reforms of aged care introduced by this government are balanced and fair, as I say. They ask people to make a contribution to their care to the extent that they are able. The reforms do not require an unreasonable contribution and they ensure the same high level of care for all people, regardless of whether or not they can pay the accommodation charge. The aged care reforms certainly do not represent a shirking of government responsibility for aged care. This government currently spends more than $3 billion per year on aged care. The average cost to the government of keeping one person in a nursing home for one year is some $30,000. This includes the cost of their care, meals, accommodation, medication, entertainment, laundry and other ancillary expenses. With the introduction of an accommodation charge, it has been estimated that, even for the wealthiest person who pays the maximum accommodation charge and income tested daily fees, the government contribution to their care would still be approximately $15,000 per year.

Census data indicates that there are approximately 2.2 million people in Australia aged over 65. This represents 12 per cent of our population. This is an increase of more than one million over the past 20 years, and the number is expected to double in the next 30 years to the year 2027. Most of Australia's baby boomers will reach retirement age between 2006 and 2016. Life expectancies are increasing, as is the average age of people in residential aged care. Currently, 7.5 per cent of Australians aged over 70 are in residential aged care. There will be proportionally fewer taxpayers able to contribute to government welfare, including aged care, through their taxation system payments in the future. Our amendments and our policies are making sure that we can sustain the sort of care that Australians expect into the next century in older people's lives.

As well as the changes in the nation's demographics, the past 20 years have also seen a marked shift in the traditional roles in our society. The predominance of the nuclear family is no longer the case. In the past there was an expectation that the mother or wife would take an active role in looking after her parents or parents-in-law. In fact, however, these days a lot of older women are still in the work force in paid employment, so ageing parents are not necessarily able to call upon the support and care of that daughter or daughter-in-law. We have to look, therefore, to more institutional care arrangements.

It is, of course, true that families continue to provide a huge amount of support and care for ageing relatives. However, the realities are that society has to look to other means of providing care in the future. There are fewer older people now moving in with their children. The 1991 census indicated that 27 per cent of 65- to 79-year-olds and 45 per cent of people aged 80 and over were in fact living alone, not as in the past when you could expect that they would perhaps shift in with their sons and daughters.

It is also true that most elderly women survive without their male partners, so more older women are living alone and they are living for much longer. The realities are that in our Australian society we have to take a long-term look and a compassionate look, but also a financially responsible look, at how we are going to manage our older people into the future. This government is doing that, unlike the previous government, which put the hard questions to one side. As we seek to do the hard yards, they now seek to scare our older people by cheap political point scoring.

Let me say too that our government is looking at innovative ways to help our older population. It is the case that older indigenous people tend not to seek accommodation in nursing homes or hostels, but in the electorate of Murray, which has a big indigenous Aboriginal population, we have Maloga, an older Aboriginal persons hostel, a superb facility run by Aboriginal people in the small town of Nathalia. Maloga is a model of what can be provided with government funding in other parts of Australia, and it is just one example of how this government looks at the varying needs of older people.

Also in Murray, to help to cater for our older ethnic minority population, this government has just very proudly opened a multicultural aged persons hostel. It contributed some $2 million towards that hostel. So, where we have had some of our older Italian, Greek, Albanian and Turkish community people worried about what to do in their old age, they can now go to the multicultural hostel and continue to enjoy meals of the sort that they have been used to all their lives, speak to staff who share their languages and have their family and friends come to visit them in an environment that they feel completely at home in.

So this government understands that there are a range of older Australians now: indigenous people, ethnic minorities and mainstream Australians. It understands that there are a lot of older women who will end up alone at the end of their days in nursing homes and hostels. But we also know that there will be some older men. We understand that older men may be a substantial minority in, say, the nursing home environment. So, again, this government has shown its innovation and its genuine caring by, for example, at the Tongala Memorial Aged Care Complex, funding what has been called the Men's Shed. This men's shed is for the older men, who are only a handful in the bigger population of older women in this community facility. The shed is exactly what these men have enjoyed all through their lives. It has tools, wood-turning equipment and metalworking equipment. It is a big tin shed with a concrete floor. It has a toilet facility and wide roller doors for wheelchair access. The equipment has been donated by a machinery manufacturer and Veterans' Affairs just the other day donated a substantial amount of money to make this Men's Shed a reality at the Tongala Aged Care Complex. This is another example of how this government is looking well beyond a generic policy at the individual needs of all our aged people.

This Aged Care Amendment Bill is very serious for older people in Australia. It is making sure that we have the funds to have sustained and adequately built facilities for all older people who need them in their declining days. I commend this bill to the House, and I know that older Australians are very grateful that this government is taking the hard decisions.

In my own electorate migrant resource centres provide a variety of office space and resources to bodies such as Spanish speaking South American migrants.
