These services are vital in terms of the settlement process and enriching this country both socially and economically. The difficulty is that the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock) is falling down very badly in the task of ensuring that migrant resource centres across this country are adequately resourced for their tasks.

I wrote to the minister on 25 June last year and drew his attention to what he undoubtedly knew any way, which was that financial advances to migrant resource centres for the vital functions that they carry out are now only being made on a quarterly basis instead of the four-year funding basis that had previously existed. That obviously provides immense problems for any organisation simply having to live on the basis of the next three months with no certainty beyond that in terms of fundamental things such as tenancy agreements, staffing contracts and the like.

The minister wrote back to me on 28 August last year indicating that he intended to have the matter of the ongoing basis for the funding of settlement services through migrant resource centres settled by 31 December. The reality is that this dithering minister simply still has not resolved the funding issues and provided the sort of certainty that migrant resource centres need. This delay in providing some sort of financial future, some sort of certainty, affects their capacity to carry out a range of things. For example, we have heard some debate which the opposition is deeply concerned about regarding the way in which employment services are being provided.

There would have been some opportunity within the government's quite unsatisfactory framework for MRCs to have tendered for those sorts of opportunities, but the absence of a long-term financial base has prevented that happening. Similarly, the capacity to tender for English language classes has been significantly reduced. Long-term leases on cheaper rates have been unable to be signed because these organisations do not know whether they can survive beyond the next three months. Essential repairs, hiring of staff, et cetera are impossible.

In my own electorate the North-West Migrant Resource Centre simply needs basic maintenance to its building. It has a leaking roof. The women's toilet needs to be put in order. There are rising damp, flaking plaster and lighting problems. The government is not being asked for money for these repairs. On the contrary, the management committee of the migrant resource centre has saved something like $40,000 over the last two years to enable them to pay for this. How can they go ahead if they are unable to plan more than three months ahead?

Even worse, the landlord of their premises in St Albans has advised them that he will fund renovations valued at $100,000 if they are prepared to sign a four-year lease, but, because of the current uncertainty, they are unable to accept that offer. It is simply unacceptable for this minister for immigration to dither. Very important and fundamental settlement services in this country that really are vital for the future social wellbeing of our nation and the satisfactory settlement of so many new settlers are simply not able to plan into the future because he is dithering and unable to make a decision.

talk.start.para: âI rise tonight to offer other members a glimpse of the rare beauty which exists in my electorate of Gilmore, arguably the most physically beautiful electorate in Australia. Our beaches, highlands, rivers, forests and lakes attract thousands of visitors each year, with local community groups playing a major role in protecting and conserving the local environment.

speech.para: Imagine, if you will, a historic village area where members of the local community gather to meet, enjoy picnics in the sunny afternoon, and watch their children play together. It is an area of village green which provides a dividing boundary between the communities of Mossvale and Bowral. With the site of the first Southern Highlands town of Bong Bong directly opposite, the green is heavy with the ghosts of the past but brimming with the potential to provide an answer to problems with cost effective, viable revegetation programs for the future.

I rise to speak tonight not to give a history lesson on Bong Bong Common, now a disused airfield, but to give support to an important initiative which I have followed since it started and which I believe emphasises our need as a community to persevere with projects which benefit the local area and Australia. This particular issue also raises the importance of cooperation between all levels of government and that of working with the community to protect and improve, as in this instance, the environment.

The conservation and preservation of local habitats and environmental areas of significance has been a key objective of the coalition government nationally. Successful programs such as bushcare, part of the Natural Heritage Trust, and Green Corps have ensured that the community groups, land users, government and industry work together to protect native bushland to increase and improve tree planting and promote the use of native vegetation into farming systems.

While national objectives are important, in applauding these successes we should not overlook what is achieved locally by community organisations and local councils. In Bong Bong, the community based organisation Greening Australia carried out direct seeding trials to revegetate the area. Direct seeding is a technique whereby tree seed is sown into the earth in a similar way that farmers sow wheat. It is an emerging technique, quick and cost effective. However, the results are not always predictable or successful.

Four years ago, when I was a councillor with the Wingecarribee Shire Council, the local shire and Greening Australia carried out a seeding program at the common. Whilst being historically important, management plans for the site include the development of the area as a garden showpiece for the highlands and construction of a major network of bush walking trails, including paths specifically designed for the blind. Already it attracts families and friends throughout the districts for picnics and meetings and provides a natural playground for children of all ages.

As part of the direct seeding program, the wider community was consulted and it took several years to decide how best to prepare the location for the trial. The results were not a resounding success to say the least, with only a handful of seeds taking root and surviving the ensuing months. However, the reason for the less than expected result was not necessarily the seeding technique. In order to professionally assess the use of direct seeding, Greening Australia has offered to do the project again. With my encouragement and total support, Wingecarribee Shire Council and Greening Australia will be working together again over the next few months to reseed the site and, with the advancement in knowledge and trials during the past four years, we are all very confident of its success.

Greening Australia will be a major contributor to bringing the airfield once again to life for the people of Bong Bong. In the same way, the coalition government's commitment to improving the environment is being promoted through the auspices of the Natural Heritage Trust and the Green Corps program, amongst others. Through programs such as coast care, dune care, bushcare, coasts and clean seas, more than 15 Gilmore volunteer groups will receive financial support for the first time to continue the work that they do for the environment. The key message is that the government's strategic investment in vegetation repair and maintenance receives added value through partnership with the community, supported by organisations such as Greening Australia.

The work that Greening Australia does would not be possible without community and business support. For example, in the first six months of its bushcare support contract, which underpins the Natural Heritage Trust bushcare program, Greening Australia has exceeded many of its national targets. For example, in six months Greening Australia has more than doubled the planned number of hectares of demonstration works and fencing to protect remnant vegetation.

Staff, volunteer members and community volunteers collected nearly 400 kilograms of native seed to be used to re-establish trees and shrubs on degraded land. In six months, nearly 54,000 seedlings have been distributed to groups and land holders. That will see areas such as the Bong Bong Common regenerated and revegetated to improve not only the land and soil but the very air we breathe. I applaud Greening Australia for continuing this program.

talk.start.para: âWhile most of this House occupy their time attacking the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Parer) and his ilk in the hope of scoring points of relatively little value to the Australian people, I will continue to address the issues at the heart of our nation's problems. It was no surprise to read recently in the Australian the disastrous report that the real unemployment figure is around 19 per cent. While I say it was no surprise, it does not diminish the horror of what those figures mean to ordinary Australians and their simple hopes for a secure future for themselves and their children.

speech.para: The Australian Bureau of Statistics has found that two million Australians want to work but are not actively looking, not ready to start or just unable to find a job. These figures do not include the hundreds of thousands of underemployed Australians forced into part-time or casual work who eke out a financially precarious existence.

The devastation wrought by previous governments and the lack of ability of the current government to correct the failed policies under which the Australian people have suffered for so long stand as a testament to either the ineptness or treachery of our so-called leaders. Those leaders are self-styled, self-centred and filled with nothing but self- interest as the continued ruination of this once great nation and its once proud people surely shows.

If the Australian people ever doubted their government's failures, then surely the 19 per cent unemployment figure would guide the way to understanding what their government has done. Successive coalition and Labor governments have allowed this crisis to occur. At the very least, they have acted irresponsibly and deserted the very Australians who elected them. Some would go further and cite what may seem to be mismanagement as actually being acts of betrayal. Either way, the consequences Australians are currently forced to endure are beyond forgiveness and will not be forgotten.

Liberal, Labor and National are all guilty of the continual pursuit of economic rationalism and it is ordinary Australians who pay the price of these failed experiments that take no account of social impact. The government's level playing field has produced this cancer of unemployment that is eating away at the fabric of our once comfortable community. For the last 25 years or so government actions have been those of the criminally negligent as they have peddled their failures and then done their level best to hide the results of their fumbling in the hope that some economic miracle would emerge. Their promises of the benefits of economic rationalism, free trade and the level playing field were lies. This 19 per cent unemployment figure from the government's own Australian Bureau of Statistics is but one of the pieces of evidence that points to their guilt.

I absolutely have to make this clear: the market wants profit only; all other considerations are secondary. Economic rationalism is a weapon wielded by governments on behalf of big business and, in particular, multinationals. To Australia, economic rationalism is a weapon of mass social destruction and it is our own government which press the button and, as yet, have not taken their finger off the trigger. Exposing us to unlimited competition from foreign countries where workers earn a dollar or two a day is destroying our industries and exporting our jobs. The proof of this is everywhere. The continuation of Labor or coalition policies can result only in further drops in our standard of living and an increasingly insecure future for Australians.

It is only with policies of reindustrialisation and the pursuit of a largely self-sufficient social and financial structure that we can arrest our government imposed decline and look towards a positive future for our own people. It is only One Nation that stands ready to implement such policies and soon the Australian people will have their chance to vote for change.

talk.start.para: âI wish to draw to the attention of the House an act on the part of the Australian Labor Party today which I consider to be nothing more than an act of political vandalism. I refer to the decision by the Australian Labor Party in the Senate to force a debate on or at least to make controversial the Health Legislation Amendment Bill No. 2 (1997). This bill, for the benefit of honourable members who may not immediately be aware of it, seeks to introduce and give effect to the removal of gap payments for medical expenses where doctors have reached an agreement with private hospitals which themselves have contracts with funds. That deals with an issue that all of us as members have to deal with on a day-to-day basis and a major irritation which is causing people to leave private health insurance.

speech.para: The bill also sought to require doctors to provide up-front quotes for the fees that they will charge patients who go into the private hospital system. The bill is to give effect to a series of trials across Australia that would, for the first time in the history of this country, require doctors to, as far as is practical, explain the charges that patients will face as they go into the system. It would also introduce the concept of informed financial consent wherever there was going to be a gap payment. In other words, prospective patients would have some idea, firstly, that a gap would exist and, secondly, what level that gap would in fact be.

The other important concept which the bill seeks to give effect to is aggregated billingâ the notion that instead of the myriad accounts that patients receive, having gone into the private hospital system, one account would be received through a billing agency; in most cases, the private hospital. So the irritation that constituents faceâin particular, older peopleâin receiving 10, 20, 30 or even in one case, as one of my constituents had, almost 70 accounts would no longer occur.

You would have thought that these were things that were not controversial. They are things that the Australian Labor Party itself supported. I find in this life, as a member of parliament, I deal with all kinds of people from frankly the incompetent right through to those whose ethics are questionable through to those who are extremely good and well motivated, but the one thing I have great difficulty with is hypocrisy. On 5 March this year the member for Dobell (Mr Lee), speaking to this bill when it went through the House of Representatives in its second reading stage, made the following comments:
The opposition is generally supportive of the content of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill No. 2 (1997) . . . the opposition will not be opposing the legislation.

He said the opposition had no objection to the major items contained in the legislation and were prepared to be constructive. The one thing about which the opposition had concern was what is described as the 35-day ruleâin other words, that after 35 days of admission in acute care and receiving an acute level of benefit the nursing home style of patient would step down to a lower level of benefit. They were concerned that this would occur for some patients from day one of admission. So the government deleted that segment of the legislation to ensure that we were able to get this through as quickly as possible and ensure that privately insured patients were able to get access to the obvious benefits contained in the bill as quickly as possible.

Today's announcement by the ALP in the Senate, under the so-called leadership of the member for Brand (Mr Beazley), is nothing short of contributing to the further demise of private health care in Australia, which is something that they did for over 13 years. Mr Keating, when Prime Minister of the country, told people they did not need private health insurance and they could rely entirely on Medicare.

The decision today will further contribute to the demise of the public hospital system because some Australians will give up private health insurance in exasperation that it appears that the politicians of this country are not able to get their act together and deal with some of the real issues that people deal with in day-to-day life.

The Morgan poll that was commissioned and released on 23 February this year by MBF found that eight out of 10 Australians believe that the decline in private health insurance is detrimental to public hospitals. That ought to be remembered when the opposition in the federal parliament are arguing about the negotiation of the Australian hospital financing agreements. It is appalling and it is political vandalism.

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 2379)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 21 October 1997:

question.para: (1) Is he able to say whether a special session of the Joint International Labour Organisation/UNESCO Committee of experts was held in Paris from 15 to 19 September 1997 to evaluate progress made in applying the recommendations concerning the status of teachers, looking in particular to training opportunities, working conditions and the extent to which teachers are integrated into the educational decision-making process.
(2) Was Australia represented at the session; if so, by whom.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The fourth special session of the joint International Labour Organisation (ILO)/UNESCO Committee of Experts on the Application of the Recommendation concerning the Status of Teachers (CEART) was held in Paris from 15-19 September 1997.
The Committee is composed of 12 members: six appointed by the Director-General of ILO and six appointed by UNESCO.

The Honourable Justice Trevor Olsson of the Supreme Court of South Australia was appointed a member of this committee by the Director-General of ILO. However all the representatives of the Committee are appointed in their own personal capacity and therefore do not represent their respective countries as such.
The meeting was held in closed session and therefore it was not possible for observers to attend.

The Committee considers allegations by teachers' organisations against governments not implementing the Recommendation or other issues relating to the status of teachers that are not covered by any of the ILO or UNESCO normative instruments. The Australian Permanent Delegation to UNESCO has been advised that there are no allegations against Australia.

The Joint ILO/UNESCO Experts Committee' s report will be presented to the Committee on Conventions and Recommendations (CR) of the UNESCO Executive Board at its next session (21-23 April 1998). The CR Committee considers questions relating to the implementation of UNESCO's standard-setting instruments and examines communications relating to cases about the exercise of human rights in UNESCO's fields of competence. The report of the Committee of Experts will be noted by the CR which will decide on further action to be taken, if any. The CR sits in private (closed) session. Australia which is not currently a member of the Executive Board will not have access to any documentation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 24 November 1997:

question.para: (1) What were the key criteria for allocating 1997-98 grants to Queensland organisations under the Community Settlement Services (CSS) Scheme.

(2) Has funding been provided previously to the Brisbane Migrant Resource Centre (BMRC) for CSS related projects to assist newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds; if so, what (a) funding was provided and (b) activities were undertaken by the BMRC.
(3)What CSS funding was granted to BMRC for 1997-98.

(4) Has funding been provided previously to the Queensland Red Cross (QRC) for CSS related projects to assist newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds; if so, what (a) funding was provided and (b) activities were undertaken by the QRC.
(5) What CSS funding was granted to the QRC for 1997-98.
(6) Have 1997-98 CSS grants been awarded to the QRC for projects or activities which the BMRC had undertaken previously and for which it had particular expertise.

(7) Is it a fact that the QRC was awarded funding for 1997-98 CSS projects for which it did not submit an application and started to receive CSS funds for particular projects from 1 October 1997 although the infrastructure and expertise required had not been established then.

(8) Has funding been provided previously for CSS related projects to assist newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds in the (a) Gympie, (b) Hervey Bay, (c) Kingaroy and (d) Mackay regions of Queensland; if so, what (i) funding was provided and (ii) activities were undertaken.
(9) What CSS funding was granted to organisations in the (a) Gympie, (b) Hervey Bay, (c) Kingaroy and (d) Mackay regions for 1997-98.
(10) How many newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds reside in the (a) Gympie, (b) Hervey Bay, (c) Kingaroy and (d) Mackay regions.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The national funding priorities for the Community Settlement Services (CSS) Scheme (formerly known as the Grant-In-Aid (GIA) scheme and the Migrant Access Projects Scheme (MAPS)) in 1997-98 were to assist recently-arrived migrants and humanitarian entrants who have demonstrated settlement needs arising from their pre-arrival experiences, and/or the cultural and language difficulties which they face on arrival in Australia.

Within this broad target group, priority groups (those identified as having the greatest need) included humanitarian entrants, isolated migrants such as the aged and refugee women in difficult situations, and new arrivals who belong to emerging communities.

Consistent with these national priorities, the specific Queensland funding priorities were refugee and humanitarian entrants (including entrants under the Special Humanitarian Program (SHP) and Special Assistance Category (SAC), those receiving On-Arrival Accommodation (OAA) and support from the Community Refugee Settlement Scheme (CRSS)); small and emerging communities; rural and remote non-English speaking communities; migrant women, youth and unemployed. In general the needs of these target groups included settlement information, settlement assistance and referral, community support and development, training and skills development, and highly skilled, culturally sensitive counselling and community work.

Funds from the Integrated Humanitarian Settlement Strategy (IHSS) were drawn upon to support innovative proposals addressing the needs of refugee and humanitarian entrants particularly those related to case coordination.

All organisations applying for funding must be capable of satisfying the criteria set out in Section 6 of my Department's Guidelines for Applicants for the Grant-In-Aid and Migrant Access Projects Schemes, February 1997.

The national funding priorities were advertised in major metropolitan and ethnic newspapers. A copy of the Guidelines, together with the State funding priorities, were provided to all organisations considering applying for funding.

(2) (a) The BMRC first received funding that would have benefited this target group in 1987-88. The funding was awarded for one full-time GIA for three years, which terminated on 31 March 1991, totalling $99,825.

In the 1988-89 funding round, BMRC received a part-time GIA for three years, which terminated on 31 March 1992, totalling $52,773. In the same year an additional part-time GIA was awarded for three years, totalling $52,733.
In the 1990-91 funding round, BMRC received one full-time GIA for three years, which continued to September 1994, totalling $135,345.
In the 1995-96 funding round, BMRC was awarded one full-time GIA for two years, which terminated on 30 September 1997, totalling $117,670.

(b) In 1987-88, activities undertaken were to assist migrants that have language and cultural interaction difficulties, particularly targeting Indo-Chinese, Turkish, Afghans and Iranians, which included refugee and humanitarian entrants.

In 1988-89, activities undertaken were to assist migrants that have language and cultural interaction difficulties, particularly targeting Turkish, Iranian and Vietnamese communities, which included refugee and humanitarian entrants. The additional grant was to target specifically the Vietnamese community.
In 1990-91, activities undertaken were to assist the Iranian community with settlement needs, which included refugee and humanitarian entrants.

In 1995-96, activities undertaken were the provision of settlement assistance to newly arrived from small and emerging communities, in particular the Kurdish and African communities which include a significant number of humanitarian entrants.
(3) BMRC was awarded $9,445 project-based funding for 1997-98 under the CSS Scheme to purchase office equipment to expand the service delivery capacity of the Centre.

(4) (a) In 1994-95 QRC received funding for one full-time GIA for three years, which terminated on 30 September 1997, totalling $122,624 to assist newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds.
(b) Activities undertaken were the provision of settlement assistance to refugees from the `Former Yugoslavia', through information, advice and referral services.
(5) QRC was awarded the following funding for 1997-98 under the CSS Scheme, supplemented by IHSS:

. $410,500 for the management of a case coordination/case management model for refugees receiving the support of my Department's OAA Program and the CRSS, and to provide a `safety net' for other humanitarian entrants in certain circumstances. Needs assessments of all eligible arrivals will be undertaken, and persons assisted to access relevant services;
. $100,000 for training and support for CRSS groups; and
. $10,000 to meet basic furniture needs of families in OAA and to assist emergency OAA cases.

(6) Since March 1996 a number of MRCs, including the BMRC, have been funded for a community worker focusing on the needs of refugee and humanitarian entrants. Through this and other DIMA funded positions, BMRC undertook case coordination in respect of refugees in the OAA program. The QRC was awarded funding in 1997-98 for an expanded case coordination/case management service for refugees in the OAA program, for CRSS entrants, and to provide a `safety net' for other humanitarian entrants in certain circumstances. In making my decisions on these grant applications, I took into consideration QRC's management of funding for the Former Yugoslav Settlement Project awarded in the 1994-95 round, and the fact that it is a very strong organisation which enjoys a good reputation.

(7) In the 1997-98 funding round BMRC, QRC and the Queensland Program for the Assistance of Survivors of Torture and Trauma (QPASTT), among other organisations, submitted applications for the provision of services for refugee and humanitarian entrants.

QRC submitted five applications for funding which were designed to facilitate the successful settlement of refugee and humanitarian entrants through material assistance, provision of information, training and support for CRSS groups, youth programs and, in relation to people from the Former Yugoslavia, continuation of the settlement support service established in 1994. These applications were consistent with elements of a proposed expanded case coordination model under the IHSS for eligible refugee and humanitarian entrants. After consideration of the mix of organisations that applied for funding, QRC was identified by my Department as the most appropriate service provider to deliver the expanded case coordination model. In making my decision I also took into consideration the continuing instability in the BMRC's Management Committee.

In their applications, organisations submit work plans for the proposed project for which funding is sought. After funding is awarded, these work plans are subject to negotiation between the organisation and the Department, prior to the commencement of funding. In this context, necessary amendments were made to enable QRC to deliver the expanded case co-ordination service.

Work plans, which provided for the employment of the equivalent of 8.75 full-time staff, were finalised in December 1997. I am advised that QRC had two full-time locum workers in place from early October 1997 to undertake service delivery, pending the outcome of formal recruitment processes. In view of this, and in accordance with the provisions of project-based funding, payment of grant monies dated from October 1997.

(8) (a) (i) (ii) Since the commencement of the GIA Scheme in 1978, no funding has been provided to organisations in the Gympie region for projects primarily focusing on assistance to newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds. In the 1994-95 round, Gympie and District Community Centreplace Inc received a three-year grant, totalling $70,322, for a part-time worker to provide an information, referral and consultancy service for migrants, especially isolated migrants, in the Gympie District. In 1991-92, Gympie and District Community Centreplace Inc, Migrant Issues Network, received a three-year grant, totalling $132,350, for a full-time worker to assist migrants access community resources and services and raise the community's awareness of migrant needs in the region. Newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds may have been assisted by these projects.

(b) (i) (ii) Since the commencement of the GIA Scheme, no funding has been provided to organisations in the Hervey Bay region for projects primarily focusing on assistance to newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds. In 1994-95, Hervey Bay Neighbourhood Centre Inc received a three-year grant, totalling $140,643, for a full-time worker to promote community development for migrants in the Wide Bay-Burnett Region. Newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds may have been assisted by this project.

(c) (i) (ii) Since the commencement of the GIA Scheme, no funding has been provided to organisations in the Kingaroy region for projects focusing on assistance to newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds.

(d) (i) (ii) Since the commencement of the GIA Scheme, no funding has been provided to organisations in the Mackay region for projects primarily focusing on assistance to newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds. In 1994-95 the Mackay Family Care and Community Support Association Inc received a three-year grant, later transferred to the Mackay Regional Council for Social Development Ltd, totalling $70,322, for a part-time worker to provide cross-cultural sensitisation of mainstream agencies and promote multiculturalism in the curriculum of the schools of the region. In 1991-92, Community Support Centre, Mackay received a three-year grant, totalling $157,200, for a full-time worker to assist migrants access community services, develop self-help support groups and to raise community awareness of migrant needs in the Mackay region. Newly arrived migrants entering on humanitarian or refugee grounds may have been assisted by these projects.

(9) (a) The Multicultural Information Network Services (which had its beginnings within the Gympie and District Community Centreplace) was awarded CSS funding of $24,179 for 1997-98 to employ a part-time worker to provide individual and group support, information and referral services. It was the view of my Department that this rural and remote region be funded to support the aging ethnic population and the settlement requirements of recent migrant arrivals isolated from their own community and services in general.

(b) The Hervey Bay Neighbourhood Centre was awarded CSS funding of $48,358 for 1997-98 to employ a full-time worker for the Wide Bay Multicultural Program to assist recently-arrived and established migrants from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds settle in the rural and remote area of the Wide Bay/Burnett region of Queensland.
(c) The St Mary's Kingaroy Catholic Social Response was awarded CSS funding of $10,000 for 1997-98 to assist recently-arrived Asian women, particularly Filipino women, to settle in the Kingaroy area.

(d) The Mackay Regional Council for Social Development on behalf of the Mackay Multicultural Network was awarded CSS funding of $48,358 for 1997-98 to address settlement needs of migrants, including humanitarian entrants; and to provide information and assist established and emerging ethnic groups. This award links into the DIMA state priorities by targeting rural and remote regions covering the six Local Government Areas of Belyando, Broadsound, Mackay, Mirani, Nebo, Pioneer, Sarina and Whitsunday as well as humanitarian entrants and small communities.

According to the 1996 Census data, which does not provide data by entry category, the number of overseas born residing in (a) the Cooloola Shire, which covers Gympie and surrounding districts, is 2,891 or 9.28% of the Shire's population, (b) Hervey Bay City is 5,456 or 14.48% of the City's population, (c) Kingaroy Shire is 795 or 7.16% of the Shire's population, and (d) Mackay City is 6,479 or 9.35% of the City's population.

Over 40% of Queensland's non-English speaking population live outside the Brisbane Statistical Division. The 1991 Census indicated that there were quite high proportions of non-English speaking migrants in the Far North and Moreton Statistical Divisions (8.5% and 7% respectively). This trend has continued for the period since the 1991 Census, with settlers indicating a preference, after the Brisbane Statistical Division, for Moreton and the Far North. Applications from Cairns, Townsville, Mount Isa, Mackay, Rockhampton, Hervey Bay, Gympie, Maroochy and the Gold Coast were therefore given priority consideration.
